revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{good article}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Charles Cruft | honorific_suffix = | image = Charlescruft.jpg | alt = | caption = A photograph of Charles Cruft, published in 1902 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1852|06|28}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1938|09|10|1852|06|28}} | death_place = [[Highbury, London]], England | death_cause = [[Myocardial infarction]] | resting_place = [[Highgate Cemetery]] | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|51.5679|-0.1488|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | monuments = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[Ardingly College]],Sussex * [[Birkbeck, University of London|Birkbeck College]], London }} | occupation = Show promoter and businessman | years_active = | known_for = [[Crufts]] Dog Show | home_town = | net_worth = £30476 9s 3d | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | spouse = {{Plainlist| * Charlotte Hutchinson (first wife) * Emma Isabel Hartshorn (second wife) }} | children = Charles Francis, Louise, Cecil Arthur and Clara Helen Grace (from first marriage) | parents = Charles Cruft (father) | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = }} '''Charles Alfred Cruft''' (28 June 1852 – 10 September 1938) was a British showman who founded the [[Crufts]] dog show. Charles first became involved with dogs when he began to work at [[Spratt's]], a manufacturer of [[dog biscuit]]s. He rose to the position of general manager, and whilst working for Spratt's in France he was invited to run his first dog show at the 1878 [[Exposition Universelle (1878)|Exposition Universelle]]. After running dog shows in London for four years, he ran his first Cruft's dog show in 1891, and continued to run a further 45 shows until his death in 1938, as well as running two cat shows in 1894 and 1895. He was involved in a range of dog breed clubs, including that for [[Schipperke]]s, [[Pug]]s and [[Borzoi]]s. He and his wife upheld a story that they never owned a dog, and instead owned a cat, however Cruft admitted to owning at least one [[Saint Bernard (dog)|Saint Bernard]] in his memoirs, published posthumously.
==Early life and Spratts== [[File:1876 ad for Spratt's Patent Meat Fibrine Dog Cakes.jpg|thumb|left|An 1876 advert for Spratt's Patent Meat Fibrine Dog Cakes, featuring the cross "trademark" that Cruft introduced]] Charles Cruft was born on 28 June 1852, one of four children.<ref name=jackson31>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 31</ref> In his youth, Charles attended [[Ardingly College]] in Sussex, and [[Birkbeck, University of London|Birkbeck College]] in London.<ref name=jackson11>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 11</ref> Cruft first followed in his father's footsteps by becoming a manufacturing jeweller but he ultimately decided that the career was not for him and left the business in 1865.<ref name=doggypeople>{{cite book|last=Lane|first=Charles Henry|title=Dog shows and doggy people|year=1902|publisher=Hutchinson|location=London|pages=84–85|url=https://archive.org/stream/dogshowsdoggypeo00lanerich#page/84/mode/2up}}</ref>
He went on to apply for the post of office boy in the Holborn shop of James Spratt, the manufacturer of [[Spratt's]] [[dog biscuit]]s. He was recruited by Spratt, who would later go on to say that Cruft had lent forward in the interview at one point whilst talking about the business and said "You know, I think this kind of business ought to do very well, I do honestly."<ref name=timesobituary>{{cite news|title=Obituary: Mr. Charles Cruft, Founder Of The Dog Show|page=14|issue=48097|newspaper=The Times|date=12 September 1938}}</ref> Cruft overhauled the bookkeeping in the shop, changing it from a system using crosses to distinguish between wholesale and retail customers to a far more detailed system.<ref name=growthtimes /> The [[Maltese cross]] that was previously used in the bookkeeping was later instead stamped onto the biscuits as a type of trademark to distinguish Spratt's biscuits from other dog biscuits.<ref name=jackson16>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 16</ref>
Several months after joining, Crufts convinced Spratt to hire a new boy to work in the shop to free himself up to solicit orders for the dog biscuits from gamekeepers, promoters of dog shows and the like. He saw a connection between improved feeding and [[Purebred (dog)|purebred]] dogs, and so supported the foundation of canine societies.<ref name=timesobituary/> As part of this new role, he was expected to have attended the "Grand National Exhibitions of Sporting and other Dogs" at [[The Crystal Palace]], London, annually between 1870 and 1872. These early shows were unsuccessful financially and were not continued.<ref name=growthtimes /> Whilst at Spratt's, Cruft gradually rose to the role of general manager, after being head of their Show Department for several years.<ref name=doggypeople/> At the age of 26, some twelve years after leaving the jewellery business, Cruft was made office manager.<ref name=jackson13>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 13</ref> The Spratt's dog biscuits became the forerunner of the modern dry [[dog food]], and under Cruft's work the company went from a single small shop to the British leader in these types of products.<ref name=timeline>{{cite news|last=Deeley|first=Dawne|title=Crufts timeline|url=http://www.dogsincanada.com/crufts-timeline|accessdate=31 August 2011|newspaper=Dogs in Canada|date=4 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927132550/http://www.dogsincanada.com/crufts-timeline|archivedate=27 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Conformation shows== In 1878, whilst still working for Spratt's, Cruft travelled across Europe to expand the biscuit business.<ref name=historydfscrufts/> Whilst in France, he was invited to run the dog show at the third [[World's Fair]] whilst he was there promoting Spratt's dog cake,<ref name=dogeatdog>{{cite news|title=Dog eat dog|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/personal-view/3602137/Dog-eat-dog.html|accessdate=30 August 2011|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=1 February 2004}}</ref> known as the [[Exposition Universelle (1878)|Exposition Universelle]].<ref name=historydfscrufts>{{cite web|title=History of dfs Crufts|url=http://www.crufts.org.uk/history-crufts|publisher=Crufts.org.uk|accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> Further offers to run shows came in for Cruft, including an offer to become Secretary of the Dutch Kennel Club, and an offer to run the livestock section of the [[Brussels]] and [[Antwerp]] International Exhibitions.<ref name=jackson18>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 18</ref> He took up job offers to run the shows for the [[Scottish Kennel Club]], and became manager of the poultry section of the shows of the [[Royal Agricultural Society of England|Royal Agricultural Society]]. He also co-founded and became club secretary of the [[Schipperke]] Club of Brussels.<ref name=jackson18/>
By the time Cruft turned 30 in 1882, Spratts had been sold to Edward Wylan who in turn promoted Charles first to "Chief Traveller", and then to general manager. Under Crufts guidance, the company diversified its product base and expanded into game bird and poultry food markets, as well as producing a range of accessories for cats and dogs. Cruft himself became secretary of the [[King Charles Spaniel|Toy Spaniel]] Club and the [[Pug]] Dog Club. He was also involved in clubs which promoted the [[Saint Bernard (dog)|Saint Bernard]] and [[Borzoi]] breeds.<ref name=jackson17 />
In 1886, Cruft was approached to run a [[Conformation showing|dog show]] for [[terrier]]s in London by the [[Kathleen, Duchess of Newcastle|Duchess of Newcastle]],<ref name=jackson18/> and so on 10 March his show opened at the [[Royal Aquarium]] in Westminster, London. Entitled "The first Great Show of all kinds of Terriers", the show received 570 entries across 57 classes and included [[Lord Alfred Paget]] among the patrons.<ref name=growthtimes>{{cite news|title=The Growth of Dog Shows; Mr. Cruft's Influence|page=8|issue=48103|newspaper=The Times|date=19 September 1938}}</ref> [[Collie]]s and several breeds of [[toy dog]]s were added by 1890.<ref name=timesobituary/>
[[File:Crufts 1891.jpg|thumb|right|Dogs on display at the 1891 Cruft's dog show]] This gradual expansion of breeds led to the creation of the first show to be named after Cruft was in 1891, when "Cruft's Greatest Dog Show" was held at the [[Royal Agricultural Hall]], [[Islington]],<ref name=timesobituary/> with part of the deal to hold the show at that location was to restrict the venue to only allowing Cruft to run dog shows at the location.<ref name=doglover>{{cite news|title=Cruft, Dog-Lover|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v5EjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cqgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4682,3085747&dq=charles-cruft&hl=en|accessdate=30 August 2011|page=8|newspaper=The Montreal Gazette|date=24 October 1938}}</ref> He designed the logo himself, the head of a Saint Bernard surrounded by a collar with a crown on top.<ref name=jackson17 /> He introduced a system where competitors would pay to enter their dogs, and make additional payments if they wished to take the dogs away each night of the three-day competition, and again pay if they wanted to take them away early on the final day.<ref name=jackson26>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 26</ref> By 1914, the show had grown in popularity until it was recognised as the largest dog show in the world and by 1936 when the show celebrated its [[Golden Jubilee]], over 10,000 dogs were entered at the event.<ref name=doglover/> Cruft's shows were frequented by Royalty, with [[Queen Victoria]] exhibiting dogs, and [[King Edward VII]] also doing so prior to becoming King. In 1893, Tsar [[Alexander III of Russia]] sent eighteen [[Borzoi]]s to compete, and from 1916 [[King George V]] entered his [[Labrador Retriever]]s regularly.<ref name=timesobituary/>
On 7 and 8 March 1894, he experimented with expanding his shows and held his first Cat conformation show. The first show had over 600 entries, becoming easily the biggest of its kind so far, with patrons that included the Duchess of Newcastle, the [[William Molyneux, 4th Earl of Sefton|Countess de Sefton]] and [[Sir Humphrey de Trafford, 3rd Baronet|Lady de Trafford]].<ref name=jackson21>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 21</ref> The publication ''Fur and Feather'' praised the new venture and encouraged more. Crufts however wasn't so sure as the initial show had lost over a hundred pounds, and entries in some of the classes were restricted to only a handful of cats.<ref name=jackson22>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 22</ref> He held a second show in March 1895,<ref name=jackson22/> which once again ''Fur and Feather'' heaped praise upon, despite the cutbacks that Cruft had initiated to make the show more profitable.<ref name=jackson24>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 24</ref> ''Fur and Feather'' announced in March 1896 that the cat show had been postponed due to Cruft's other business commitments, but he never went on to run such a show again.<ref name=jackson24/>
In 1896, Cruft designed special train carriages to carry competition dogs for his shows from around the country.<ref name="jackson26"/> Cruft was Secretary of the Ranelagh Fox Terrier Show in 1901, and together with several colleagues including [[Sir Humphrey de Trafford, 3rd Baronet|Sir Humphrey de Trafford]] created the National Terrier Club, and from the second show onwards on 21 June 1902, the show became known as the National Terrier Show. Cruft continued as Secretary of the club until 1914 when Sir William Savory took on the role.<ref name=ntchistory>{{cite web|last=Owen|first=Catherine|title=Early Club History|url=http://www.nationalterrier.co.uk/html/aboutus.htm|publisher=National Terrier Club|accessdate=31 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331122659/http://www.nationalterrier.co.uk/html/aboutus.htm|archivedate=31 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Despite the fact that he gave away very few details about himself to the press, to make them concentrate more on promotion of his shows, he did not always see eye to eye with all members of the media. One newspaper refused to publish his name at all, and whenever it made reference to Cruft's dog shows, it simply referred to them as "a dog show in Islington".<ref name=jackson31 />
==Death and legacy== [[File:KC Cavalier at Crufts 2007.jpg|thumb|right|A Cavalier King Charles Spaniel at the Crufts dog show in 2007]] After running his 45th Crufts show in 1938, he fell ill. By the late summer he was recovering, but he died due to a heart attack at around 5:30am on 10 September. Tributes came in from media agencies, with ''[[Our Dogs]]'' calling him "the man who made dog shows",<ref name=jackson28>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 28</ref> and comparisons with the American showman [[P. T. Barnum]].<ref name=jackson29>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 29</ref>
The funeral occurred on 21 September.<ref name=jackson28/> Cruft was buried in a tomb in the western area of [[Highgate Cemetery]], London. It would become [[Grade II listed]] on 14 May 1974.<ref name=tomblisted>{{cite web|title=Tomb of Charles Cruft in Highgate (western) Cemetery, Hampstead|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-478288-tomb-of-charles-cruft-in-highgate-wester|publisher=British Listed Buildings.co.uk|accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> The [[London Borough of Islington]] placed a [[Blue plaque|plaque]] commemorating Charles Cruft at Ashurst Lodge, Highbury Grove, N5.<ref name=plaque>{{cite web|title=A-Z of Islington's Plaques|url=http://www.islington.gov.uk/leisure/heritage/heritage_borough/bor_plaques/a_z_plaques.asp|publisher=London Borough of Islington|accessdate=25 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
His will left £30476 [[£sd|9s 3d]] to his family and friends, with the majority going to his second wife, Emma, and £2000 going to his daughter Clara. Two grandchildren, Charles and Betty Cruft each received £500, and two nephews, Kenneth and John Hartshorn, each received the same.<ref name=jackson31 /> Eight nieces, one great nephew and a young cousin each received £50. One of his maids, Kate Hempstead, who had worked for him for over thirty years also received £50. His cousin Lt Arthur Cruft received £100, while Cruft's secretary Miss E. Harrington, who had worked on the Crufts dog shows since 1925 received £500.<ref name=jackson32>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 32</ref>
At the time of his death in 1938, it was thought that his wife, Emma Cruft, would continue to run the dog shows with the help of the show's secretary, Miss Hardingham.<ref name=growthtimes /> After running the show in 1939, Mrs Cruft sold the show to [[The Kennel Club]], however due to [[World War II]], it wasn't until 1948 when they ran the show for the first time. The show would remain being called Cruft's until 1974, when during a rebrand the [[apostrophe]] was dropped, resulting in the show being called Crufts, which it continues to be called at the present.<ref name=historydfscrufts />
==Family life== [[File:George Cruft's Family Tomb, Highgate.jpg|thumb|right|Family tomb of Charles Cruft in the western end of [[Highgate Cemetery]].]] Cruft's first marriage was to Charlotte Hutchinson in 1878. Together they had four children, Charles Francis, Louise, Cecil Arthur and Clara Helen Grace. His second marriage was to Emma Isabel Hartshorn in 1894, they had no children.<ref name=jackson31/> He remained in close contact with his children, and involved each of them in the dog show business. Such was the relationship with his daughter Clara, who was nicknamed "Birdie", that she alone was listed in his second wife's will as a step daughter.<ref name=jackson32/>
His wife Emma stated in her book, ''Mrs Charles Cruft's Famous Dog Book'', published in 1949 that there was an unwritten rule that both herself and her husband couldn't own any dogs for fear of making others believe that they favoured one breed over another, even going as far to say "we were determined to own a pet, so we took the least like of resistance and kept a – CAT!"<ref name=jackson19>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 19</ref> This was disproved in Cruft's memoirs, published posthumously in ''Charles Cruft's Dog Book'' in 1952, where Cruft explained that he had lived in households which had [[German Shepherd Dogs|Alsatians]] and [[Borzoi]]s. He went on to make particular reference to the fact that he and his wife Emma had owned at least one [[Saint Bernard (dog)|Saint Bernard]];<ref name=jackson20>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 20</ref> the same breed of dog he had used in his creation of the Crufts logo.<ref name=jackson17>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 17</ref>
At the time of the [[United Kingdom Census 1901]], Cruft was living at 325 Holloway Road, N7 with his wife Emma, his father Charles, a boarder named Albert Causfield and a servant named Alice Gregory. He listed his profession as "show promoter".<ref>{{cite web|last=Dean|first=Charles|title=Census tells 'tail' of Dog Show founder|url=http://www.islington.gov.uk/Council/CouncilNews/PressOffice/2011/03/PR4352.asp|work=9 March 2011|publisher=Islington Council|accessdate=30 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824075848/http://www.islington.gov.uk/Council/CouncilNews/PressOffice/2011/03/PR4352.asp|archivedate=24 August 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Emma would go on to outlive Charles, she died at the age of 82 on 5 September 1950.<ref>{{cite news|title=England's Dog Show Operator Succumbs at 82|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6G9gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=23ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1556,1240426&dq=charles-cruft&hl=en|accessdate=30 August 2011|page=24|newspaper=Star News|date=6 September 1950}}</ref> At the time of his death, he was living at 12 Highbury Grove, London, N5. His staff included a cook, a chauffeur, two maids and a gardener. Additionally, he owned a country home called Windmill Farm, in [[Coulsdon]], Surrey.<ref name=jackson27>[[#jackson1990|Jackson (1990)]]: p. 27</ref>
==References== ;Specific {{Reflist|2}}
;General *{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Frank|title=Crufts|year=1990|publisher=Pelham|location=London|isbn=978-0-7207-1889-8|ref=jackson1990}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cruft, Charles}} [[Category:1852 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:People educated at Ardingly College]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Burials at Highgate Cemetery]] [[Category:Crufts]] [[Category:Alumni of Birkbeck, University of London]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Christophe Rocancourt | image = | caption = | birth_name = Christophe Thierry Rocancourt | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1967|7|16}} | birth_place = [[Honfleur]], [[Calvados (department)|Calvados]], [[France]] | nationality = French | other_names = Christopher Rocancourt
Christopher Rockefeller
Christopher Reyes
Christopher De Laurentiis
Christopher de la Renta
Christopher Loren
Christopher Lloyd
Fabien Ortuna
Prince Galitzine Christo
Michael van Hoven | weight = | occupation = [[Impostor]], [[confidence trick|Confidence man]] | spouse = Gry Park
[[Pia Reyes]] (1996–?) | children = 3 | parents = Daniel Rocancourt & Annick Villers }} '''Christophe Thierry Daniel Rocancourt''', sometimes also called '''Christopher Rocancourt''' (born 16 July 1967), is a French [[impostor]] and [[confidence trick|confidence man]] who [[fraud|scammed]] affluent people by masquerading in turn as a French nobleman, the heir to the [[Rockefeller]] family or family member of a celebrity. ==Biography== Rocancourt told ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' in a 2006 broadcast that his mother sometimes worked as a [[prostitute]] and his father was an [[alcoholic]] who took Christophe to an [[orphanage]] when the boy was 5. His first big con was made in Paris, where he faked the [[deed]] to a property that he did not own, which he then "sold" for USD $1.4 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/11770944/ns/dateline_nbc/t/catch-him-if-you-can/#.WNwQ9IWcGP8|title=Catch Him If You Can|author=Mike Taibbi|date=March 12, 2006|accessdate=March 29, 2017|publisher=Dateline}} Making his way to the [[United States]], Rocancourt used at least a dozen aliases, and got the rich and powerful to invest in his schemes, he told ''Dateline'', by tapping into their greed. He convinced them that he, too, was rich by paying for their lavish dinners in cash. He once estimated to ''Dateline'' that his various schemes/ventures netted him at least [[US$]]40 million, but this cannot be confirmed. In [[Los Angeles]], he pretended to be a [[movie producer]], ex-[[boxing]] champion or [[venture capitalist]], also claiming to be the illegitimate son of [[Sophia Loren]], the nephew of [[Oscar de la Renta]] and [[Dino De Laurentiis]], and he associated himself with various celebrities: he lived for a time with [[Mickey Rourke]], and apparently convinced actor [[Jean-Claude Van Damme]] to produce his next movie. He was also in talks with [[Jermaine Jackson]] to develop a line of fragrances inspired by [[Michael Jackson]] songs.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/style/2001/01/rocancourt200101|title=The Counterfeit Rockefeller|author=Bryan Burrough|date=October 3, 2007|accessdate=March 29, 2017|publisher=Vanity Fair}} Rocancourt, using the name Christopher De Laurentiis, married Gry Park in 1992 with whom he had a child. He married ''[[Playboy]]'' model [[Pia Reyes]] in May 1996, and they had a son, Zeus. Beside being married to Pia Reyes, according to the press, he lived with ''Playboy'' model Rhonda Rydell for six months. She did not know Rocancourt was married, and said he had told her he was French nobility, the son of a countess. In 1997 police raided Rocancourt's hotel suite, and in 1998 he was arrested for an involvement in a shootout before he jumped [[bail]]. In 1999 he was freed of charges of forging [[passport]]s after he had bribed [[State Department]] employees to get a passport. He was arrested in 2000 in the [[Hamptons]] for an unpaid hotel bill, then jumped bail and relocated to Canada where he assumed the identity of [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] driver Michael van Hoven. On April 27, 2001 he and Reyes were detained in [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], [[British Columbia]], Canada, and Rocancourt was later charged with defrauding an elderly couple; Reyes was released after convincing authorities that she had no part in the scam, much less any idea of her husband's criminal activities.{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/christopher-rocancourt-one-of-lifes-truly-great-pretenders-has-no-regrets---honestly/article4138322/|title=Christopher Rocancourt, one of life's truly great pretenders, has no regrets - honestly|author=Rod Mickleburgh|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=March 21, 2009|accessdate=March 29, 2017}} Rocancourt served a year in prison before being extradited to New York and pleading guilty to charges of [[theft]], [[grand larceny]], [[smuggling]], [[bribery]], [[perjury]] and [[fraud]] against 19 victims. In September 2003, the plea resulted in a fine of $9 million, an order to pay $1.2 million in restitution and a term of three years and ten months in federal prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/fake-rockefeller-gets-jail-time/|title=Fake Rockefeller Gets Jail Time|author=Jarrett Murphy|date=October 21, 2003|accessdate=March 29, 2017|publisher=CBS News}} While being held in Canada, Rocancourt wrote an autobiography in which he ridiculed his victims. In [[Switzerland]], police have connected him with a jewel theft, and barred him from the country for 14 years; this expired 2016. Rocancourt returned to Paris in October 2005 after completing his prison sentence. He lived with former Miss France [[Sonia Rolland]], and they had a daughter together, named Tess. They announced their split in early 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.purepeople.com/article/sonia-rolland-et-christophe-rocancourt-leur-histoire-d-amour-est-terminee_a6738/1|title=Sonia Rolland et Christophe Rocancourt : leur histoire d'amour est terminée !|date=April 10, 2008|accessdate=March 29, 2017|publisher=Purepeople}} In July 2009, French filmmaker [[Catherine Breillat]] accused Rocancourt of scamming her out of 700,000 [[euro|€]]. Breillat, who was diagnosed with a [[cerebrovascular disease]] in 2004, accused him of taking advantage of her due to her mental incapacity.{{cite web|last=Groves|first=Don|title=Breillat's new twist on Sleeping Beauty|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/films/blog-articles/120022/breillat-s-new-twist-on-sleeping-beauty|work=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]]|accessdate=15 January 2013|date=9 August 2010}} Due to this event, the film ''Bad Love'', with Rocancourt and model [[Naomi Campbell]], was cancelled. Breillat told a French journalist that her first meeting with Rocancourt was the worst day of her life, even worse than the day when she was diagnosed with her cerebrovascular disease. In 2012, Rocancourt was convicted of "abus de faiblesse" ("abuse of weakness") for taking Breillat's money, and sentenced to prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/actualite-france/2012/02/17/01016-20120217ARTFIG00667-huit-mois-de-prison-ferme-pour-rocancourt.php|title=Christophe Rocancourt sort de prison et prépare un livre|author=Delphine de Mallevoüe|date=February 18, 2012|accessdate=March 29, 2017}} ==In popular culture== The American Court TV (now [[TruTV]]) television series ''Mugshots'' released an episode on the Christophe Rocancourt titled ''Chris Rocancourt - A French Con'', aired in 2013.{{cite web|title=MUGSHOTS: CHRIS ROCANCOURT – A FRENCH CON|url=http://filmrise.com/mugshots-chris-rocancourt-a-french-con-2/|website=FilmRise|accessdate=8 November 2017|date=1 December 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|1597715}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051231222315/http://www.courttv.com/onair/shows/mugshots/indepth/rocancourt.html CourtTV video files about Rocancourt] * [http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/04/18/60minutes/main550070.shtml ''Counterfeit Rockefeller'' (CBS News)] * [http://www.cnn.com/2003/LAW/05/20/ctv.rocancourt/ ''Faux Rockefeller 'I misled people''' (CNN)] * [http://playermagazine.com/ManageArticle.asp?C=840&A=34 Con artist's luck runs out in British Columbia]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.purepeople.com/article/christophe-rocancourt-aurait-arnaque-catherine-breillat-a-hauteur-de-650-000-euros_a35146/1 Pure People] * [http://www.normandythenandnow.com/the-rockefeller-from-honfleur-and-other-lies/ The Rockefeller from Honfleur and other lies] {{Scams and confidence tricks}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rocancourt, Christopher}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:French fraudsters]] [[Category:French people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People extradited from Canada to the United States]] [[Category:People from Honfleur]]

revision.text:
'''College eSports''' began in about 2010 as different schools began forming eSports clubs that play any of the variety of eSports games in college tournaments. Varsity collegiate eSports began in 2014 when [[Robert Morris University Illinois]] announced a scholarship-sponsored [[League of Legends]] team. Since then, the scene has ballooned to include around 50 programs, with a national governing body known as the National Association of Collegiate Esports as the main home for most of those organizations. == Organizations ==
=== Tespa === [[Tespa]] is a leading collegiate eSports organization that was founded on September 2, 2013. Tespa being the leader it is, has connections with [[ESPN]], [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]] and other platforms for broadcasting its tournaments. It has over 270 chapters across North America and over 102,000 Tespa Members/ alumni. Tespa has 1200+ schools that have participated in Tespa tournaments with 30,000+ competitors. Over the years, Tespa have offered a total of $3 million in scholarships to student gamers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tespa |url=https://tespa.org |website=Tespa |publisher=Tespa |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== National Association for College eSports === National Association of Collegiate Esports was introduced as a pioneer in the new and exciting Esports era. The non-profit organization has partnered with over 80 schools to create a revenue allowing student athletes to receive approximately 9 million in scholarships. NACE was founded on July 28, 2016 at the first Collegiate eSports Summit held in Kansas City, MO. NACE endorses the Harrisburg University eSports Tournament, which had collegiate teams battle for prize money of $50,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nacesports.org|title=National Association for College Esports|last=|first=|date=|website=National Association for College Esports|publisher=National Association for College Esports|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
== Current Programs == In 2018, there were at least 73 college varsity eSports programs in NACE or other divisions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/21152905/college-esports-list-varsity-esports-programs-north-america|title=List of varsity esports programs spans North America|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-11-27|language=en}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !School !Location !Athletics |- |[[Ashland University]] |[[Ohio]] |[[NCAA Division II|Division II]] |- == Scholarship Programs ==
=== CCU eSports Scholarship === Cincinnati Christian University eSports scholarship option was announced on September 4, 2018. CCU will begin their intercollegiate competition in 2019-2020. The games which the program covers are ''[[League of Legends]]'', ''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]]'', ''[[Fortnite]]'', ''[[Rocket League]]'', ''[[Super Smash Bros.]]'', ''[[Madden NFL|Madden]]'', ''[[NBA 2K]]'', and ''[[FIFA (video game series)|FIFA]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Esports Coming to CCU |url=http://www.ccuathletics.com/article/1012.php |website=CCU |publisher=Cincinnati Christian University |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Daemen eSports Scholarship === Daemen College announced the start of eSports scholarships in January 29, 2018. They are competing in East Coast Conference. Their eSports program includes [[League of Legends]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Daemon Creates Esports Team |url=https://www.daemen.edu/news/daemen-creates-esports-team-collegiate-programs-increase-nationally |website=Daemon |publisher=Daemon University |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Indiana Tech Esports Scholarship === Indiana Tech University announced their eSports scholarship in August, 16, 2016. At first, they launched 35 scholarships and began in Fall 2017. The university's state-of-the-art gaming arena was finished in October 2016. Their eSport program covers [[League of Legends]] and [[Hearthstone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.indianatech.edu/news/indiana-tech-offer-esports-scholarships-2017/|title=Indiana Tech Offers Esports Scholarship|last=|first=|date=|website=Indianatech|publisher=Indiana Tech University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018|}}</ref>
=== Maryville University Esports === Maryville is one of the most successful college eSports programs. The program won the most prestigious [[League of Legends]] tournament on May 6, 2016. Their eSport program covers [[League of Legends]] and Heroes of the Storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.maryville.edu/studentlife/esports-clubs/|title=eSports Clubs|last=|first=|date=|website=Maryville|publisher=Maryville University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Southwest Baptist University === Southwest Baptist's eSports program began in Fall 2016. The reason for creating an eSports scholarship program at Southwest Baptist University is the Xbox One Arena, created for intramural competition. The arena allows students to interact with the community while playing video games. SBU competes in the Collegiate eSports Association (CESPA and National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA). Their eSports program covers League of Legends.<ref>{{cite web |title=SBU Launches Varsity Esports Program for Fall 2016 |url=https://www.sbubearcats.com/news/2016/8/9/sbu-launches-varsity-esports-program-for-fall-2016.aspx?path=esports |website=Southwest Baptist University |publisher=Southwest Baptist University |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Stephens College eSports Scholarship === Stephens College is all women's school. They are competing in National Association of Collegiate eSports (NACE). Their eSports program covers Overwatch.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stephens.edu/student-life/esports/|title=eSports|last=|first=|date=|website=Stephens|publisher=Stephens University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== The NYU Game Center === To earn a scholarship at NYU, players do not only need to know how to play fighting games but also must want design games. Students who wants to study graphic design at NYU can apply for the [[Evolution Championship Series|EVO]] fighting tournament. The scholarship is based on the funds raised during the [https://gamecenter.nyu.edu/evo/ EVO tournament].<ref>{{cite web |title=EVO |url=https://gamecenter.nyu.edu/evo/ |website=Game Center NYU |publisher=New York University |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== UCI eSports === UCI is the first public university to create an eSports program. Currently, they are recognized as one of the best in the world. The idea to start eSport program at UCI came during the summer of 2015. In Spring 2016, the first scholarships where awarded. On September 23, 2016 they opened an eSports arena.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://esports.uci.edu/about/|title=Esports - University of California|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=University of California|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== University of Utah Scholarship === The eSports program at University of Utah was created in 2017. Utah made a tryout in which over 200 players competed, 33 of them make a cut. Currently they consider themselves as one of the top eSports programs in the country. Their eSports program covers [[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]], [[League of Legends]], [[Rocket League]] and [[Hearthstone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.utahbusiness.com/new-home-team-varsity-gaming-university-utah/|title=The New Home Team: Varsity Gaming at the University of Utah|last=|first=|date=|website=Utah Business|publisher=Utah Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== University of Harrisburg === University of Harrisburg announced during a press conference held on July 26th, 2018 their roster with 16 players. 500 players tried out for these 16 spots. The program officially began in 2018. They are competing in National Association of Collegiate Esports.Their eSports program covers [[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]] and [[League of Legends]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.invenglobal.com/articles/5776/full-athletic-scholarships-stipend-and-housing-harrisburg-university-reveals-esports-team|title=Full athletic scholarships, stipend and housing: Harrisburg University Reveals Esports Team|last=|first=|date=|website=Invenglobal|publisher=Invenglobal|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Robert Morris University === Robert Morris University first had an eSports program in Fall 2013. In 2014, they decided to give full scholarships to their eSports players. Their program covers [[League of Legends]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmueagles.com/coach/0/147|title=2018-19 esports Coaches|last=|first=|date=|website=RMUEagles|publisher=Robert Morris University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref> ==Controversy==
===Sexism=== In a 2016 interview with Steph Harvey conducted by the British Broadcasting Corporation, she explains the controversy of women in eSports. She describes during the interview that video games are thought to be only played by men. She delivers accounts of her experiences while participating in and receiving degrading comments due to her gender. This in turn is the reason she feels more women do not participate in ESports. The constant stigma placed upon them and backlash from the male competitors makes women feel outcast for something designed for anyone to participate.<ref>{{cite news |title=100 Women 2016: The women challenging sexism in e-sports |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-37992322 |accessdate=24 November 2018 |agency=British Broadcast Corporation |publisher=British Broadcast Corporation |date=21 November 2016}}</ref>
===Racism=== In a article posted by The ESports Observer, they talk about the controversy of different players interacting with one another during matches. One of the biggest complaints seen is racist comments being exchanged during matches. This not only caused conflicts between the players but cause issues for the game publisher. One way this is being curbed though is punishing the player after they receive a number of complaints about their comments during gameplay.<ref>{{cite web |title=Who Is Responsible for Policing Racism in Esports? |url=https://esportsobserver.com/policing-racism-esports-dota2/ |website=The Esports Observer |accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
== References == <references /> [[Category:Esports]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2017}} Elephants are an integral part of the [[Mysore Dasara]] Festival. The elephants form the core of the [[Mysore]] Dasara procession on the [[Vijayadashami]] day. The lead [[elephant]] carries the [[Golden Howdah]] ([[Chinnada Ambari]]) with the Goddess [[Chamundeshwari]] in it.
==Arrival== The Elephants start arriving to [[Mysore]] city in groups. They arrive to Mysore a month or so before the start of the actual festivities and they undergo practice for their march on the final day. The elephants are accompanied by their respective keepers or [[Mahout]]s. The elephants are usually brought in trucks and are occasionally walked the 70-km distance from their home base in the [[Nagarahole National Park]] to Mysore. Villagers greet the sacred animals all along their designated trekking route. As each party of pachyderms arrives at the Veerana Hosahalli forest checkpost in [[Hunsur]] taluk, from the forest, they are received by the [[District]] Minister, a host of officials and prominent persons from Mysore and people from nearby villages. The villagers perform folk dances, and beat drums and sing songs to welcome the elephants. This in keeping with the royal tradition of the Mysore Maharajas.
==Royal feast== While in their respective camps the elephants are served '[[Ragi mudde]]', a mixture of [[Finger millet|ragi]] and horse gram and fodder branches. But when they are royal guests in the royal city of Mysore preparing for Dasara, they are served with ‘royal’ food till the grand Dasara finale - [[Jamboo Savari]]. The elephants get to eat uddina bele (black gram), [[green gram]], [[wheat]], boiled [[rice]], [[onion]] and vegetables in the mornings and evenings. They get [[rice]], [[peanut|groundnut]], [[coconut]], [[jaggery]] and [[sugarcane]] with some salt to add taste to the diet after they return from their regular rehearsals. This food is served twice a day. They also get branch fodder like [[banyan]] leaves. Extra care is taken while serving food to the jumbos. High-calorie and protein-rich food is served to the elephants to improve their physical fitness. They carry a lot of weight at the procession and for that, they need strength. Hence they are fed with rich food. The food served in the morning is laced with pure [[butter]] for flavour. Besides nutritious food, [[vitamin]] doses are also injected so as to balance the diet. An elephant eats 400 kilograms of [[fodder]] in a day in the forests. The food served to them in [[Mysore]] contains high calories and is more than what they eat in the jungles.
==Choosing the elephants== The Dasara Elephants are usually caught by the elephant trainers via the [[Khedda]] operation. During the Wodeyar rule, the elephants thus caught were inspected in an open field for strength, personality, and character. The walking styles, weaknesses to seduction, the facial charisma were some of the factors considered for selection. Then the chosen elephants were trained for the festival. It is said that the king himself would oversee the training. Sometimes abandoned young elephants are also trained for dasara.
==The abode== The abode of the elephants during the rest of the year is usually their training camps and the surrounding [[National Parks]]. There are around 70 tamed elephants in exclusive camps at [[Dubare]], Hebballa, Moorkal, Kallalla, Nagarahole, Veeranahosahalli, Metikuppe, Sunkadakatte, Bandipur, Moolehole, K. Gudi and Bheemeshwari. About 240 [[mahout]]s and kavadis take care of the needs of these elephants and develop a bond with them.
==The elephants== The elephants are named in Kannada and usually have the names of [[Hinduism|Hindu]] mythological and historical figures. Elephants [[Elephant Drona|Drona]] and [[Balarama (elephant)|Balarama]] carried the idol of deity Chamundeshwari housed in the [[Golden Howdah]] for a combined total of 30 years. Balarama took up the responsibility after Drona was electrocuted in 1998 at Nagarahole National Park. Balarama has been granted retirement after 13 years. The 52-year-old [[Arjuna (elephant)|Arjuna]] replaced Balarama and carried the [[Golden Howdah]] during the Dasara 2012 Jamboo Sawari procession at Mysore on 24 October 2012. The other elephants participating in the event are Bharatha, Kanthi, Gayathri, Kokila, Sri Rama, Abhimanyu, Gajendra, Biligiriranga, Vikram, Varalakshmi, and Sarojini.
==External links== *[http://www.mysoresamachar.com/dasara_03_elephants.htm Mysoresamachar] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160405202656/http://www.kamat.com/kalranga/prani/elephants/dasara_elephants.htm Potpuri] *[http://www.hindu.com/2006/09/08/stories/2006090807310500.htm Hindu News] *[http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:pSxA8_4LVyoJ:www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/Sep42006/district18717200693.asp+Elephant+Balarama&hl=en&gl=uk&ct=clnk&cd=10 Royal Feast]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

page.title: Destruction of the Country House exhibition

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''The Destruction of the Country House 1875-1975''' was an exhibition held at the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] (V&A) in 1974, commissioned by V&A Director [[Roy Strong]] and curated by [[John Harris (curator)|John Harris]], [[Marcus Binney]] and [[Peter Thornton]] (then working, respectively, at the [[Royal Institute of British Architects|Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA)]], ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'' magazine and the V&A Department of Furniture and Woodwork).
The exhibition included a "Hall of Destruction", decorated with falling columns and illustrations of some of the [[Destruction of country houses in 20th-century Britain|thousand country houses demolished since 1875]], brought down by falling estate incomes, rising costs, death duties, and damage caused by government requisitioning during the [[Second World War]].
Described as a "landmark" exhibition,<ref>[http://www.ribaj.com/index.php/feature/article/to_the_manor_born/ RIBAJournal.com]</ref> the graphic illustration of the scale of destruction of Britain's built heritage changed public opinion, and encouraged moves to protect the country houses that remained.
The success of the exhibition inspired the formation of the campaigning group, [[SAVE Britain's Heritage]], in 1975 - a year that was designated as European Architectural Heritage Year by the [[Council of Europe]] - but the changed public mood could not prevent the sale of the extraordinary collection of art and furniture at [[Mentmore Towers]] in 1975, and of the empty building itself in 1977, to pay taxes following the death of [[Harry Primrose, 6th Earl of Rosebery]] in 1973.
The exhibition was followed in 1977 and 1979 by two further exhibitions at the V&A on British architectural heritage: ''Change and Decay: The Future of our Churches'' (curated by Strong, Binney and [[Peter Burman]]), and then ''The Garden: A Celebration of a Thousand Years of British Gardening'' (organised by Harris).
==Further reading== * ''The Destruction of the Country House''. Roy Strong, Marcus Binney, John Harris, 1974. Thames and Hudson. {{ISBN|0-500-24094-9}}
==External links== *[http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/s/save-britains-heritage-1975-2005-30-years-of-campaigning/# SAVE Britain’s Heritage 1975-2005: 30 Years of Campaigning] from the V&A
==References== <references/>
{{coord|51.496302|-0.172078|type:event_region:GB|display=title}}

{{Infobox writer | name = Feraliminal Lycanthropizer | image = Feraliminal Lycanthropizer.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Cover of 1990 pamphlet
"Feraliminal Lycanthropizer" | alt = Cover of 1990 pamphlet
"Feraliminal Lycanthropizer"}} The '''Feraliminal Lycanthropizer''' is a fictional machine invented by American writer [[David Woodard]], whose 1990 pamphlet of the same title speculates on its history and purpose.Woodard, D., [http://juniperhills.net/feraliminallycanthropizer.pdf "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer"] ([[San Francisco]]: Plecid Foundation, 1990). The brief, anonymously published work describes a vibration referred to as thanato-auric waves, which the machine electrically generates by combining three [[infrasonic]] sine waves (3 Hz, 9 Hz and 0.56 Hz) with concomitant tape loops of unspecified spoken text (two beyond the threshold of decipherability, and two beneath the threshold).[[Jack Sargeant (writer)|Sergeant, J.]], [http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/news/696235/posts "Sonic Doom"], ''[[Fortean Times]]'', Dec 2001. {{cquote|This combination of drastically contrasting emotional trigger mechanisms results in an often profound behavioral enhancement which occurs strikingly soon (within moments) after the user enters and remains in the auricular field of the machine.''}} The premise is that a mind-altering technology has for decades, at the behest of American intelligence during the [[Cold War]], been withheld from scrutiny. Dispensing [[Information sensitivity|sensitive information]] in the interest of enhancing civilian life, the author shares his own notes as well as those left by earlier researchers. ==Etymology== The name Feraliminal Lycanthropizer is composed of two [[portmanteau]] words. The first, Feraliminal, is a combination of the Latin [[:wikt:ferus|''ferus'']] (wild animal) and [[:wikt:limen|''limen'']] (threshold), while the second, Lycanthropizer, combines the Ancient Greek root [[:wikt:lycanthrope|''lycanthrope'']] (werewolf) with a generic suffix, [[:wikt:-izer|-''izer'']], conferring [[agency (philosophy)|agency]]. Together the words suggest something hidden that triggers wild or aggressive conduct.Bruun, J., "Dreamachines, Wishing Machines or Feraliminal Lycanthropizers, Anyone?," in Kerekes, D., ed., ''Headpress: Journal of Sex, Religion, Death—Issues 24-27'' ([[Manchester]]: Headpress, 2002), p. 32. ==Legacy and influence== Despite the pamphlet's brevity and obscurity, its story has acquired mythic overtones, and readers have since made extraordinary attempts to replicate the Feraliminal Lycanthropizer and/or invoke its described "animalizing effects on human subjects tested within measurable vibratory proximity."Anon., [http://cripo.com.ua/?sect_id=4&aid=139861 "Inaudible sound that kills"], ''Украина Криминальная'', Jul 31, 2012. The machine's neologistic name has thus appeared in conjunction with disparate music groups and artists, as indicated: * The Feraliminal Lycanthropizers, a free improvisation ensemble founded in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] in 2000Afe Records, [http://www.aferecords.com/artists/craig_hilton.htm Craig Hilton bio]. * "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer," a 2004 song by one-man English [[doom metal]] band [[:it:Uncertainty Principle|Uncertainty Principle]]Uncertainty Principle, [http://www.metal-archives.com/albums/Uncertainty_Principle/Acoustical_Weapons_Division/163695 ''Acoustical Weapons Division''] (2004), [[Encyclopaedia Metallum|MA]]. * ''The Feraliminal Lycanthropizer'', an art exhibition featuring work by [[Peter Coffin (artist)|Peter Coffin]] and other artists, curated by [[Craig Kalpakjian]], at [[Drew_Heitzler#Champion_Fine_Art|Champion Fine Art]], Los Angeles, 2005Champion Fine Art, [http://www.kalpakjian.com/champion.html ''The Feraliminal Lycanthropizer''], May 6–28, 2005. * "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer," a song by [[Prague]]-based American [[Ambient music|ambient]] duo Schloss Tegal, featured on their 2006 album ''The Myth of Meat''Schloss Tegal, [https://www.discogs.com/Schloss-Tegal-The-Myth-Of-Meat/release/757464 ''The Myth of Meat''] ([[Moscow]]: Waystyx, 2006), [[Discogs]].Schloss Tegal, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9poNoeUmbg0 "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer"] (audio only), [[YouTube]], Sep 7, 2015. * ''Feraliminal'', a 2006 album by Russian [[Black metal#Stylistic divisions|ambient black metal]] band AdoniramAdoniram, [http://www.metal-archives.com/albums/Adoniram/Feraliminal/165240 ''Feraliminal''] ([[Izhevsk]]: Firstborn Chaos Productions, 2006), MA. * Lycanthropizer, a pseudonym adopted circa 2006–2011 by the lead vocalist of American [[black metal]] band Miasmic[http://www.metal-archives.com/artists/Lycanthromancer/212334 Lycanthromancer] (artist page), MA. * Feraliminal Lycanthropizer, an active [[goregrind]]/[[:de:porngrind|porngrind]] band founded in [[Yaroslavl, Russia]] in 2009[http://vk.com/flgrind Feraliminal Lycanthropizer] (band page), [[VK (social networking)|VK]]. * "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer," a song by English [[electronica]] duo [[Posthuman (band)|Posthuman]], featured on their 2011 album ''Datalinks''Posthuman, [http://posthuman.bandcamp.com/track/feraliminal-lycanthropizer "Feraliminal Lycanthropizer"] (2011), [[Bandcamp]]. * "Feraliminal Tremens," a 2012 song by [[Chicago]]-based experimental electronic project Blood Rhythms (Arvo Zylo) with [[Christopher Turner]] and [[Michael Esposito (paranormal investigator)|Michael Esposito]]Blood Rhythms, [https://www.discogs.com/TOMB-Blood-Rhythms-Universal-Holocaust-Feraliminal-Tremens/release/3978224 "Feraliminal Tremens"] (Chicago: Land of Decay, 2012), [[Discogs]]. * ''Feraliminal'', a 2016 anti-cosmosWeepunkt, A., [http://totgehoert.blogspot.com/2016/05/tape-gehort-vircolac-feraliminal.html "Tape gehört: Vircolac ''Feraliminal''"], Totgehört, May 14, 2016. cassette EP by Irish [[death metal]] band VircolacVircolac, [http://www.irishmetalarchive.com/releases/vircolac-feraliminal/ ''Feraliminal''] (2016), Irish Metal Archives; [http://www.metal-archives.com/albums/Vircolac/Feraliminal/567983 ''op. cit.''], MA. Feraliminal Lycanthropizer-themed works also include: * ''Progressive Lycanthropy'', a 2010 cassette and booklet by [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]-based [[psychoacoustic]] artist Thomas Bey William BaileyBailey, T. B. W., [http://thomasbeywilliambailey.bigcartel.com/product/progressive-lycanthropy-cassette-and-booklet ''Progressive Lycanthropy''] ([[Kuala Lumpur]]: Mirror Tapes, 2010), Big Cartel.{{refn|"The [three pieces] on this cassette were built up from a Feraliminal Lycanthropizer drone, an experimental binaural frequency supposedly used by the military as an audio truth serum or combat stimulant. As the name suggests, this technique was meant to hurl individuals into 'wolf-like' states in which they would careen between poles of focused rage and woozy ecstasy."—Bailey|group=n}} * ''Wolf Hunter'', a novel by [[Denver]]-based [[Horror fiction|horror]] writer J.L. Benét, winner of the 2013 Independent Publisher Book AwardIndependent Publisher, [http://www.independentpublisher.com/article.php?page=1653 "2013 IPPY Awards Results"], May 2013.Hughes, A., [http://fantasticreviews.blogspot.cz/2014/02/battle-of-books-bracket-seven-first_9.html Review of ''Wolf Hunter''], Fantastic Reviews, Feb 9, 2014. ==Scientific and historical inconsistencies== Apart from its title and the term ''thanato-auric'', other hitherto unknown coinages introduced in Woodard's text are, in order of appearance: ''Plecidic'', ''aurotic'', ''nucleopatriphobic'' and ''Eugenaestheticus''. Moreover, journalistic coverage appears to have roundly debunked the myth of the machine. According to ''Fortean Times'', "[L]egends about the machine challenge belief; besides being credited with sparking unrestrained orgies, it has...been blamed for the sex-and-strangulation deaths of six youths. Some, who claim to have used the machine, have felt themselves become mentally stronger and their will more focused. [The] essay claims that 'a Catalan national using the machine daily over a period of five or six weeks eventually managed to ingratiate himself to Adolf Hitler [and] persuade his quarry to adopt the swastika as high totem and emblem of the burgeoning National Socialist Conference.' Such stories are, clearly, beyond belief. There is no evidence that the Feraliminal Lycanthropizer exist[ed] or could have such effects." In ''TechnoMage'', a compendium of writings on technology and the occult, author Dirk Bruere relates, "The recording '...contains two infrasonic frequencies, 3hz and 9hz, which, combined, generate a lower, third frequency of 0.56hz.' They do not."Bruere, D., ''TechnoMage'' ([[Bedford, England]]: Dirk Bruere, 2009), [https://books.google.com/books?id=qXJXAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA369&dq=feraliminal&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 369–370].{{rp|369–370}} Paranormal researcher [[Michael Esposito (paranormal investigator)|Michael Esposito]] opines, "I’m not sure the Feraliminal Lycanthropizer is as effective as a woman leaning against the spin cycle of a [[Washing machine|Maytag]]."Zylo, A., [http://blog.wfmu.org/freeform/2013/03/interview-with-michael-esposito.html "Interview with M. Esposito"], [[WFMU#Online broadcasting and blogging|WFMU's Beware of the Blog]], Mar 14, 2013. ==See also== * [[Bioacoustics]] * [[Orgasmatron]] * [[Wunderwaffe]] == Notes == {{Reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Occult}} {{Authority control}} *{{YouTube|U6Gk-deapg4|Feraliminal Lycanthropizer, "Именины Сердца"}}, Oct 20, 2010. *[http://vk.com/flgrind?z=video25378047_456239032%2Ff49aea02b783663b7d%2Fpl_post_-13094904_885 Feraliminal Lycanthropizer, live at Coyote Brutal Fest] on [[VK (social networking)|VK]], Mar 6, 2016. *{{YouTube|C5hKfSIevuY|Feraliminal Lycanthropizer}}, Dec 23, 2016. {{DEFAULTSORT:Feraliminal Lycanthropizer}} [[Category:American speculative fiction]] [[Category:Fictional technology]] [[Category:Devices to alter consciousness]] [[Category:Urban legends]]

{{distinguish|Flash Crash of 1962}} A '''flash crash''' is a very rapid, deep, and volatile fall in [[Security (finance)|security]] prices occurring within an extremely short time period. A flash crash frequently stems from [[trade]]s executed by [[black-box trading]], combined with [[high-frequency trading]], whose speed and interconnectedness can result in the loss and recovery of billions of dollars in a matter of minutes and seconds.<ref name=RareEvents>{{cite web|last=Bozdog|first=Dragos|title=Rare Events Analysis of High-Frequency Equity Data|ssrn=2013355|website=papers.ssrn.com|publisher=Wilmott Journal, pp. 74–81, 2011|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
== Occurrences == Four notable{{According to whom|date=February 2017}} flash crashes have occurred {{As of|2016|October|lc=}}:{{Citation needed|date=February 2017}} * [[2010 Flash Crash|May 6, 2010, Flash Crash]] * [[AP Tweet Flash Crash of 2013|April 23, 2013, Flash Crash]] * Frankenshock,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3b4f6c14-9c9a-11e4-971b-00144feabdc0|title=Pound’s plunge joins growing list of ‘flash crashes’|last=|first=|date=7 October 2016|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 October 2017}}</ref> or Flash Crash Swiss Franc in January 15, 2015<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/switzerlands-central-bank-lost-51-billion-and-the-franc-crashed-04-2015-7|title=Switzerland's central bank lost $51 billion and the franc is getting hammered|work=Business Insider|access-date=2017-10-30|language=en}}</ref> * Flash Crash of the British Pound on October 6, 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/oct/07/what-caused-pound-flash-crash-brexit-fallen-sterling|title=What caused the pound's flash crash?|last=Davies|first=Rob|date=2016-10-07|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-30|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>
=== The Flash Crash === {{Main|2010 Flash Crash}}
This type of event occurred on [[2010 Flash Crash|May 6, 2010]]. A $4.1 billion trade on the [[New York Stock Exchange|New York Stock Exchange (NYSE)]] resulted in a loss to the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] of over 1,000 [[Dollar|points]] and then a rise to approximately previous value, all over about fifteen minutes. The mechanism causing the event has been heavily researched and is in dispute. On April 21, 2015, the U.S. Department of Justice laid "22 criminal counts, including fraud and market manipulation" against [[2010 Flash Crash#Evidence of market manipulation and arrest|Navinder Singh Sarao]], a trader. Among the charges included was the use of [[Spoofing (finance)|spoofing]] algorithms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-22/mystery-trader-armed-with-algorithms-rewrites-flash-crash-story|title=How a Mystery Trader With an Algorithm May Have Caused the Flash Crash|date=2015-04-22|newspaper=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-02-08}}</ref>
=== 2017 Ethereum Flash Crash === On June 22, 2017, the price of [[Ethereum]], the second-largest digital [[cryptocurrency]], dropped from more than $300 to as low as $0.10 in minutes at [[GDAX]] exchange. Suspected for market manipulation or an account takeover at first, later investigation by GDAX claimed no indication of wrongdoing. The crash was triggered by a multimillion-dollar selling order which brought the price down, from $317.81 to $224.48, and caused the following flood of 800 [[stop-loss order|stop-loss]] and [[margin funding liquidation]] orders, crashing the market.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/22/ethereum-price-crash-10-cents-gdax-exchange-after-multimillion-dollar-trade.html |title=Ethereum briefly crashed from $319 to 10 cents in seconds on one exchange after ‘multimillion dollar’ trade |last=Kharpal|first=Arjun |date=22 June 2017 |work=[[CNBC]] |accessdate= 24 June 2017 }}</ref>
=== British pound flash crash === On October 7, 2016, there was a flash crash in the value of [[pound sterling|sterling]], which dropped more than 6% in two minutes against the US dollar. It was the pound's lowest level against the dollar since May 1985. The pound recovered much of its value in the next few minutes, but ended down on the day's trading, most likely due to market concerns about the impact of a "[[hard Brexit]]"—a more complete break with the [[European Union]] following Britain's 'Leave' [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|referendum vote in June]]. It was initially speculated that the flash crash may have been due to a [[Fat-finger error|fat-finger trader error]] or an [[Trading algorithm|algorithm]] reacting to negative news articles about the [[British Government]]'s European policy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/dfb375be-8c23-11e6-8cb7-e7ada1d123b1|title=Pound struggles to recover after plunging 6% in 2 minutes|date=7 October 2016|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref>
=== Other crashes === In October 2013, a flash crash occurred on the [[Singapore Exchange]] which wiped out $6.9 billion in [[capitalization]] and saw some [[stock]]s lose up to 87 percent of their value. The crash resulted in new regulations being announced in August 2014. Minimum trading prices of 0.20 cents per share would be introduced, [[short position]]s would be required to be reported, and a 5 percent [[Collateralized debt obligation|collateral]] [[Tax|levy]] implemented. The exchange said the measures were to curb excessive [[speculation]] and potential [[Share (finance)|share]] [[price manipulation]].<ref name="SGXCurbs">{{cite news|title=Singapore Exchange regulators change rules following crash|url=http://www.singaporenews.net/index.php/sid/224382417/scat/a677a0718b69db72/ht/Singapore-Exchange-regulators-change-rules-following-crash|accessdate=2 August 2014|publisher=''Singapore News.Net''}}</ref>
Two short-lived (less than a second) movements (more than 1%) in several (40 and 88) stock prices followed by recovery were reported for November 25, 2014.<ref>{{cite url|publisher=MarketWatch|title=Two mini-flash crashes rock stock market Tuesday| url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/two-mini-flash-crashes-rock-stock-market-2014-11-25?dist=tcountdown| accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Stock market crash]] * [[Fat-finger error|Fat-Finger Error]]

{{for|the 2015 film|Going to America (film)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Going to America | series = [[Father Ted]] | image = Batch 1871.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | series_no = 3 | episode = 8 | airdate = 1 May 1998 | production = | writer = [[Arthur Mathews (writer)|Arthur Mathews]], [[Graham Linehan]] | director = [[Graham Linehan]], [[Andy de Emmony]] | guests = [[Tommy Tiernan]] (Fr. Kevin),
[[Jeff Harding (actor)|Jeff Harding]] (Fr. Buzz Cagney),
Mark Doherty (Fr. Alan),
Hugh B. O'Brien (Eugene),
[[Brian Eno]] (Fr. Brian Eno) | episode_list = List of Father Ted episodes | prev = [[Night of the Nearly Dead]] | next = Final }} "'''Going to America'''" is the final episode of the [[Channel 4]] sitcom ''[[Father Ted]]''. It is the eighth episode of the third series and the 25th episode overall. The show's star [[Dermot Morgan]] died the day after filming was completed. ==Synopsis== [[File:Batch 2091.jpg|left|thumb|200px|Father Kevin falls victim to depression.]] After [[Father Ted Crilly|Ted]] prevents a [[clinical depression|depressed]] Father Kevin ([[Tommy Tiernan]]) from jumping to his death at the "It's Great Being a Priest" conference, an American priest, Father Buzz Cagney ([[Jeff Harding (actor)|Jeff Harding]]), asks him if he will come to a parish in [[Los Angeles]]. Ted cannot wait and excitedly tells [[Father Jack Hackett|Jack]], [[Father Dougal McGuire|Dougal]] and [[Mrs. Doyle]], who incorrectly think they will be able to come with him. Ted does not have the heart to tell them otherwise and brings them to the airport, leaving them there while he gets on the plane. However, Ted has second thoughts when Buzz mentions the gang culture around Ted's new parish in Los Angeles and its violent state. Realising he is in serious trouble, Ted abandons going on his trip and rejoins Jack, Dougal and Mrs Doyle. It transpires that the three of them never wanted to go to the States anyway, with the possible exception of Jack, who yells 'Feck!' when he learns of what has gone wrong, though the promise of a drink cheers him up. The group leaves the airport and heads for home, and Ted resigns himself to the fact he is probably never going to escape [[Craggy Island]]. ===Alternate ending=== The episode was always intended to be the last ''[[Father Ted]]''; in the original script, the last scene was to be set at the "It's ''Still'' Great Being a Priest" conference with Father Kevin once again on the window ledge and once again Ted arriving on the ledge, except this time it is not to stop him from jumping but to join him, because he was depressed that the intended trip to America fell through and he would have to stay on Craggy Island forever. This ending was abandoned in favour of a montage of clips from all three series of the show, although this was not (as believed) because of the death of [[Dermot Morgan]]. Rather, the writers did not think that their original ending was very funny. The episode was filmed on 27 February 1998, the day before Morgan died. ==Production== This episode does not normally contain a credits sequence at the end, as it is replaced by the clips montage. The episode's guest cast is listed alongside the lead actors in the opening credits. While filming the scene in which Ted dances to "[[Theme from Shaft|Theme from ''Shaft'']]," Tommy Tiernan continually flubbed his lines. As a result, Dermot Morgan was required to perform the dance repeatedly, despite pains in his heart. In a 2009 interview, Tiernan speculated that this contributed to Morgan's fatal heart attack the following day.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotpress.com/features/interviews/TOMMY%20TIERNAN%20IN%20THE%20CHAT%20ROOM/5849883.html?|title=TOMMY TIERNAN IN THE CHAT ROOM|work=hotpress.com|last=Tyaransen|first=Olaf|date=28 September 2009|accessdate=1 November 2012}} ===Montage clips=== A clip is shown from each episode, in reverse order of airdate. * Mrs Doyle fainting ("[[Night of the Nearly Dead]]") * Ted kicking Bishop Brennan up the arse ("[[Kicking Bishop Brennan up the Arse]]") * Ted shouting at the soccer team ("[[Escape from Victory]]") * A crow stealing Jack's glasses ("[[The Mainland (Father Ted)|The Mainland]]") * Dougal driving the milkfloat ("[[Speed 3]]") * Chris on a boat, watched by Ted and Dougal ("[[Chirpy Burpy Cheap Sheep]]") * Ted inadvertently resembling Hitler ("[[Are You Right There, Father Ted?]]") * Mrs Doyle falling off the windowsill ("[[A Christmassy Ted]]") * "It's me. In the nip. With a dog." ("[[Flight into Terror]]") * Mrs Doyle showing "GO ON" flashcards to Fr Stack ("[[New Jack City (Father Ted)|New Jack City]]") * Ted injured by a cross ("[[Cigarettes and Alcohol and Rollerblading]]") * Imelda winning the Lovely Girls competition ("[[Rock-a-Hula Ted]]") * Tom "taking care" of a toy rabbit ("[[The Plague (Father Ted)|The Plague]]") * Part of the "My Lovely Horse" music video ("[[Song for Europe (Father Ted)|Song for Europe]]") * "Picnic Area" sign hitting Ted ("[[The Old Grey Whistle Theft]]") * Mrs Doyle bathes Dougal ("[[Tentacles of Doom]]") * The Dancing Priest ("[[Think Fast, Father Ted]]") * Ted, Jack and Dougal in the wrong caravan ("[[Hell (Father Ted)|Hell]]") * The Monkey Priest throwing books around ("[[Grant unto Him Eternal Rest]]") * Ted being shocked by Polly's tale ("[[And God Created Woman (Father Ted)|And God Created Woman]]") * The Third Age of Elvis ("[[Competition Time (Father Ted)|Competition Time]]") * "Down With This Sort Of Thing" and "Careful Now" ("[[The Passion of St Tibulus]]") * Fr Stone on the toilet, Ted in the bath ("[[Entertaining Father Stone]]") * Ted on the 'Crane of Death' ("[[Good Luck, Father Ted]]") The final shot is an exterior view of the parochial house at dusk. Ted and Dougal say goodnight to each other (stock audio from the episode "[[New Jack City]]") and the light in their bedroom is switched off. ==Trivia== *Father Kevin is cured of his depression by listening to a cover of [[Issac Hayes]]' "[[Theme from Shaft|Theme from ''Shaft'']]" by Eddie & the Soul Band, before falling back into depression by the song "[[Exit Music (For a Film)]]" by [[Radiohead]]. *[[Brian Eno]] makes a brief cameo appearance in the episode as Father Brian Eno. Linehan has claimed that the idea came as "we used to see him around [[Kilburn, London|Kilburn]] wearing a fez."{{cite web|last1=Linehan|first1=Graham|title=Twitter post|url=https://twitter.com/Glinner/status/21351832408301568|website=Twitter|accessdate=12 May 2015}} *When Ted discusses a fictional [[Harrison Ford]] film with Dougal, the details mentioned are identical to those of ''Firestorm'', a fictional film previously described by characters in the American sitcom ''[[Seinfeld]]''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|Father Ted#Going to America|Going to America}} * {{IMDb episode|0578509}} {{Father Ted}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Going to America}} [[Category:Father Ted episodes]] [[Category:Television series finales]] [[Category:1998 British television episodes]] [[Category:Mental illness in fiction]] [[Category:Fiction with alternate endings]]

The '''Ignite Film Festival''' is a [[Christian film|Christian]] short film festival held annually in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]]. The major goal of the festival is to develop young Christian film makers and to encourage people to be creative about communicating the truths of the [[Bible]]. Each film is no longer than five minutes and includes the theme for the year.
==Ignite Film Festival themes== Each year, Ignite Film Festival has a theme of an item or action being incorporated in the entry films to ensure that they are unique. * 2013 - Joy * 2012 - Hope * 2011 - Life * 2010 - Love * 2009 - Animals * 2008 - Rock or Stone * 2007 - Light * 2006 - Fire * 2005 - H2O * 2004 - Parable
==Winners== * 2013 - White as Snow - Directed by Leah Beanland * 2012 - Centre - Directed by Michael Snowdon * 2011 - Abide With Me - Directed by Matt Nelson and Damien Madden. Sanctity of Life Category - Dear Mum - Directed by Anthony Vallejos * 2010 - Remember Me - Directed by David Cairns * 2009 - Enmity - Directed by Matthew Carson-Drever * 2008 - Atarashii Tabidachi * 2007 - A Great Light * 2006 - Arthur * 2005 - Love Thy Neighbour - Directed by James Cogswell & Will Mitchell * 2004 - The Great Feast - Directed by Tim Andrews
==External links== * [https://vimeo.com/ignitefilmfest Official Web Site]

'''International ICT Expo''' is organised by the [[Hong Kong Trade Development Council]] (HKTDC) and is held at the [[Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Hong Kong electronic, lighting and ICT fair opens |url=http://www.cctv.com/program/bizchina/20090414/101076.shtml |publisher=[[China Central Television]] |date=14 April 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2010 }}</ref> in April every year.
The Expo includes the following product and service zones: Enterprise Solutions; Computer & [[Peripherals]]; [[Telecommunication|Telecom]], [[Computer network|Networking]] & [[Wireless]] Technologies; [[IT Outsourcing]]; Digitainment & [[Multimedia]]; e-Logistics & Retail Technologies; Home-grown Innovations; and Trade Related Services.
==Related events== *[Hong Kong Electronics Fair (Spring Edition)]https://web.archive.org/web/20100119132936/http://hkelectronicsfairse.com/index.htm *[Hong Kong Int'l Lighting Fair (Spring Edition)]http://hklightingfairse.hktdc.com/ *[Hong Kong Electronics Fair (Autumn Edition)]http://hkelectronicsfairae.hktdc.com/ *electronicAsia https://web.archive.org/web/20100217063349/http://electronicasia.hktdc.com/index.htm
==References== {{Reflist}} ;Notes {{refbegin}} <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> *http://www.cacci.org.tw [http://www.cacci.org.tw/CACCI%20Profile/2009/March2009/FAIRS200903.pdf] *http://www.ipr.co.kr/eng/ipre2-1.asp [http://www.ipr.co.kr/eng/ipre2-1.asp] http://www.ipr.co.kr/eng/ipre2-1.asp {{refend}}
==External links== * {{Official website|ictexpo.hktdc.com/index.htm}} * [http://ictexpo.hktdc.com/press_rel/press_main.htm Press releases]
