{{DEFAULTSORT:International Reaction To Fitna}} [[Category:Geert Wilders]] [[Category:Islam-related controversies]] [[Category:Islam in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Events relating to freedom of expression]] [[Category:Foreign relations of the Netherlands]] [[Category:2008 controversies]] [[Category:International responses to media-related events]]

{{continuum mechanics|cTopic=[[Solid mechanics]]}} The '''J-[[integral]]''' represents a way to calculate the [[strain energy release rate]], or work ([[energy]]) per unit fracture surface area, in a material.<ref name=VanVliet>[http://www.stellar.mit.edu/S/course/3/fa06/3.032/index.html Van Vliet, Krystyn J. (2006); "3.032 Mechanical Behavior of Materials"]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The theoretical concept of J-integral was developed in 1967 by Cherepanov<ref>G. P. Cherepanov, '' The propagation of cracks in a continuous medium'', Journal of Applied Mathematics and Mechanics, 31(3), 1967, pp. 503–512.</ref> and in 1968 by [[James R. Rice|Jim Rice]]<ref name=Rice68>J. R. Rice, ''A Path Independent Integral and the Approximate Analysis of Strain Concentration by Notches and Cracks'', Journal of Applied Mechanics, 35, 1968, pp. 379–386.</ref> independently, who showed that an energetic [[contour integral|contour path integral]] (called ''J'') was independent of the path around a [[Fracture|crack]].
Later, experimental methods were developed, which allowed measurement of critical fracture properties using laboratory-scale specimens for materials in which sample sizes are too small and for which the assumptions of Linear Elastic [[Fracture Mechanics]] (LEFM) do not hold,<ref name="Lee and Donavon">Lee, R. F., & Donovan, J. A. (1987). J-integral and crack opening displacement as crack initiation criteria in natural rubber in pure shear and tensile specimens. Rubber chemistry and technology, 60(4), 674–688. [https://dx.doi.org/10.5254/1.3536150]</ref> and to infer a critical value of fracture energy ''J''<sub>Ic</sub>. The quantity ''J''<sub>Ic</sub> defines the point at which large-scale [[plasticity (physics)|plastic]] yielding during propagation takes place under mode one loading.<ref name="VanVliet" /><ref name=Meyers>Meyers and Chawla (1999): "Mechanical Behavior of Materials," 445–448.</ref>
The J-integral is equal to the [[strain energy release rate]] for a crack in a body subjected to monotonic loading.<ref name="Yoda80">Yoda, M., 1980, ''The J-integral fracture toughness for Mode II'', Int. J. Fracture, 16(4), pp. R175–R178.</ref> This is generally true, under quasistatic conditions, only for [[linear elasticity|linear elastic]] materials. For materials that experience small-scale [[yield (engineering)|yield]]ing at the crack tip, ''J'' can be used to compute the energy release rate under special circumstances such as monotonic loading in [[fracture mechanics|mode III]] ([[antiplane shear]]). The strain energy release rate can also be computed from ''J'' for pure [[power-law hardening]] [[plasticity (physics)|plastic]] materials that undergo small-scale yielding at the crack tip.
The quantity ''J'' is not path-independent for monotonic [[fracture mechanics|mode I]] and [[fracture mechanics|mode II]] loading of elastic-plastic materials, so only a contour very close to the crack tip gives the energy release rate. Also, Rice showed that ''J'' is path-independent in plastic materials when there is no non-[[proportional loading]]. Unloading is a special case of this, but non-proportional plastic loading also invalidates the path-independence. Such non-proportional loading is the reason for the path-dependence for the in-plane loading modes on elastic-plastic materials.
== Two-dimensional J-integral == [[File:Integrale-J 2D.png|200px|right|thumb|Figure 1. Line J-integral around a notch in two dimensions.]] The two-dimensional J-integral was originally defined as<ref name="Rice68" /> (see Figure 1 for an illustration) :<math> J := \int_\Gamma \left(W~dx_2 - \mathbf{t}\cdot\cfrac{\partial\mathbf{u}}{\partial x_1}~ds\right) = \int_\Gamma \left(W~dx_2 - t_i\,\cfrac{\partial u_i}{\partial x_1}~ds\right) </math> where ''W''(''x''<sub>1</sub>,''x''<sub>2</sub>) is the [[strain energy density]], ''x''<sub>1</sub>,''x''<sub>2</sub> are the coordinate directions, '''t''' = ['''σ''']'''n''' is the [[stress (physics)|surface traction]] vector, '''n''' is the normal to the curve Γ, ['''σ'''] is the [[Cauchy stress tensor]], and '''u''' is the [[displacement vector]]. The strain energy density is given by :<math> W = \int_0^{[\varepsilon]} [\boldsymbol{\sigma}]:d[\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}] ~;~~ [\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}] = \tfrac{1}{2}\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}\mathbf{u}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla}\mathbf{u})^T\right] ~. </math> The J-integral around a crack tip is frequently expressed in a more general form{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} (and in [[Einstein notation|index notation]]) as :<math> J_i := \lim_{\varepsilon\rightarrow 0} \int_{\Gamma_\varepsilon} \left(W(\Gamma) n_i - n_j\sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial u_k(\Gamma, x_i)}{\partial x_i}\right) \, d\Gamma </math> where <math>J_i</math> is the component of the J-integral for crack opening in the <math>x_i</math> direction and <math>\varepsilon</math> is a small region around the crack tip. Using [[Green's theorem]] we can show that this integral is zero when the boundary <math>\Gamma</math> is closed and encloses a region that contains no [[Mathematical singularity|singularities]] and is [[simply connected]]. If the faces of the crack do not have any [[surface traction]]s on them then the J-integral is also [[path independence|path independent]].
Rice also showed that the value of the J-integral represents the energy release rate for planar crack growth. The J-integral was developed because of the difficulties involved in computing the [[Stress (mechanics)|stress]] close to a crack in a nonlinear [[Elasticity (physics)|elastic]] or elastic-[[Plasticity (physics)|plastic]] material. Rice showed that if monotonic loading was assumed (without any plastic unloading) then the J-integral could be used to compute the energy release rate of plastic materials too.
:{| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" width="80%" style="text-align:left" !Proof that the J-integral is zero over a closed path |- |To show the path independence of the J-integral, we first have to show that the value of <math>J</math> is zero over a closed contour in a simply connected domain. Let us just consider the expression for <math>J_1</math> which is :<math> J_1 := \int_\Gamma \left(W n_1 - n_j\sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_1}\right) \, d\Gamma </math> We can write this as :<math> J_1 = \int_\Gamma \left(W \delta_{1j} - \sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_1}\right)n_j \, d\Gamma </math> From [[Green's theorem]] (or the two-dimensional [[divergence theorem]]) we have :<math> \int_{\Gamma} f_j~n_j~d\Gamma = \int_A \cfrac{\partial f_j}{\partial x_j}~dA </math> Using this result we can express <math>J_1</math> as :<math> \begin{align} J_1 & = \int_A \cfrac{\partial}{\partial x_j}\left(W \delta_{1j} - \sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_1}\right) dA \\ & = \int_A \left[\cfrac{\partial W}{\partial x_1} - \cfrac{\partial\sigma_{jk}}{\partial x_j}~\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_1} - \sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial^2 u_k}{\partial x_1 \partial x_j}\right]~dA \end{align} </math> where <math>A</math> is the area enclosed by the contour <math>\Gamma</math>. Now, if there are '''no body forces''' present, equilibrium (conservation of linear momentum) requires that :<math> \boldsymbol{\nabla}\cdot\boldsymbol{\sigma} = \mathbf{0} \qquad \implies \qquad \cfrac{\partial\sigma_{jk}}{\partial x_j} = 0 ~. </math> Also, :<math> [\boldsymbol{\varepsilon}] = \tfrac{1}{2}\left[\boldsymbol{\nabla}\mathbf{u}+(\boldsymbol{\nabla}\mathbf{u})^T\right] \qquad \implies \qquad \varepsilon_{jk} = \tfrac{1}{2}\left(\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_j} + \cfrac{\partial u_j}{\partial x_k}\right) ~. </math> Therefore, :<math> \sigma_{jk}\cfrac{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_1} = \tfrac{1}{2}\left(\sigma_{jk}\cfrac{\partial^2 u_k}{\partial x_1 \partial x_j} + \sigma_{jk}\cfrac{\partial^2 u_j}{\partial x_1 \partial x_k}\right) </math> From the balance of angular momentum we have <math>\sigma_{jk} = \sigma_{kj}</math>. Hence, :<math> \sigma_{jk}\cfrac{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_1} = \sigma_{jk}\cfrac{\partial^2 u_j}{\partial x_1 \partial x_k} </math> The J-integral may then be written as :<math> J_1 = \int_A \left[\cfrac{\partial W}{\partial x_1} - \sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_1}\right]~dA </math> Now, for an elastic material the stress can be derived from the stored energy function <math>W</math> using :<math> \sigma_{jk} = \cfrac{\partial W}{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}} </math> Then, if the elastic modulus tensor is homogeneous, using the [[chain rule]] of differentiation, :<math> \sigma_{jk}~\cfrac{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_1} = \cfrac{\partial W}{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}~\cfrac{\partial\varepsilon_{jk}}{\partial x_1} = \cfrac{\partial W}{\partial x_1} </math> Therefore, we have <math>J_1 = 0 </math> for a closed contour enclosing a simply connected region without any elastic inhomogeneity, such as voids and cracks. |}
:{| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" width="80%" style="text-align:left" !Proof that the J-integral is path-independent |- |[[Image:J integralPathIndep.png|200px|right|thumb|Figure 2. Integration paths around a notch in two dimensions.]] Consider the contour <math>\Gamma = \Gamma_1 + \Gamma^{+} + \Gamma_2 + \Gamma^{-} </math>. Since this contour is closed and encloses a simply connected region, the J-integral around the contour is zero, i.e. :<math> J = J_{(1)} + J^{+} - J_{(2)} - J^{-} = 0 </math> assuming that counterclockwise integrals around the crack tip have positive sign. Now, since the crack surfaces are parallel to the <math>x_1</math> axis, the normal component <math>n_1 = 0</math> on these surfaces. Also, since the crack surfaces are traction free, <math>t_k = 0 </math>. Therefore, :<math> J^{+} = J^{-} = \int_{\Gamma} \left(W n_1 - t_k~\cfrac{\partial u_k}{\partial x_1}\right) \, d\Gamma = 0 </math> Therefore, :<math> J_{(1)} = J_{(2)} </math> and the J-integral is path independent. |}
==J-integral and fracture toughness==
For isotropic, perfectly brittle, linear elastic materials, the J-integral can be directly related to the [[fracture toughness]] if the crack extends straight ahead with respect to its original orientation.<ref name="Yoda80" />
For plane strain, under [[fracture mechanics|Mode I]] loading conditions, this relation is :<math> J_{\rm Ic} = G_{\rm Ic} = K_{\rm Ic}^2 \left(\frac{1-\nu^2}{E}\right) </math> where <math>G_{\rm Ic}</math> is the critical strain energy release rate, <math> K_{\rm Ic}</math> is the fracture toughness in Mode I loading, <math>\nu</math> is the Poisson's ratio, and ''E'' is the [[Young's modulus]] of the material.
For [[fracture mechanics|Mode II]] loading, the relation between the J-integral and the mode II fracture toughness (<math>K_{\rm IIc}</math>) is :<math> J_{\rm IIc} = G_{\rm IIc} = K_{\rm IIc}^2 \left[\frac{1-\nu^2}{E}\right] </math>
For [[fracture mechanics|Mode III]] loading, the relation is :<math> J_{\rm IIIc} = G_{\rm IIIc} = K_{\rm IIIc}^2 \left(\frac{1+\nu}{E}\right) </math>
== Elastic-plastic materials and the HRR solution == [[File:HRRSingularity plain.svg|300px|right|thumb|Paths for J-integral calculation around a notch in a two-dimensional elastic-plastic material.]] Hutchinson, Rice and Rosengren <ref>{{Citation|last=Hutchinson|first= J. W. |year=1968|title= Singular behaviour at the end of a tensile crack in a hardening material|journal= Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids|volume=16|number=1|pages= 13–31.|url=http://www.seas.harvard.edu/hutchinson/papers/312.pdf|doi=10.1016/0022-5096(68)90014-8}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last1=Rice|first1=J. R.|first2=G. F.|last2= Rosengren|title=Plane strain deformation near a crack tip in a power-law hardening material|journal=Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids|volume= 16|number=1|year=1968|pages= 1–12.|url=http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?AD=AD0659300|doi=10.1016/0022-5096(68)90013-6}}</ref> subsequently showed that J characterizes the [[Mathematical singularity|singular]] stress and strain fields at the tip of a crack in nonlinear (power law hardening) elastic-plastic materials where the size of the plastic zone is small compared with the crack length. Hutchinson used a material [[constitutive law]] of the form suggested by [[Ramberg-Osgood plasticity|Ramberg and Osgood]]:<ref>{{Citation|last1=Ramberg|first1=Walter|first2=William R.|last2=Osgood|title= Description of stress-strain curves by three parameters|journal= US National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics|volume=902|year=1943}}</ref> :<math>\frac{\varepsilon}{\varepsilon_y}=\frac{\sigma}{\sigma_y}+\alpha\left(\frac{\sigma}{\sigma_y}\right)^n</math> where ''σ'' is the [[Cauchy stress tensor|stress]] in uniaxial tension, ''σ''<sub>y</sub> is a [[yield (engineering)|yield stress]], ''ε'' is the [[infinitesimal strain theory|strain]], and ''ε''<sub>y</sub> = ''σ''<sub>y</sub>/''E'' is the corresponding yield strain. The quantity ''E'' is the elastic [[Young's modulus]] of the material. The model is parametrized by ''α'', a dimensionless constant characteristic of the material, and ''n'', the coefficient of [[work hardening]]. This model is applicable only to situations where the stress increases monotonically, the stress components remain approximately in the same ratios as loading progresses (proportional loading), and there is no [[flow plasticity theory|unloading]].
If a far-field tensile stress ''σ''<sub>far</sub> is applied to the body shown in the adjacent figure, the J-integral around the path Γ<sub>1</sub> (chosen to be completely inside the elastic zone) is given by :<math> J_{\Gamma_1} = \pi\,(\sigma_{\text{far}})^2 \,. </math> Since the total integral around the crack vanishes and the contributions along the surface of the crack are zero, we have :<math> J_{\Gamma_1} = -J_{\Gamma_2} \,. </math> If the path Γ<sub>2</sub> is chosen such that it is inside the fully plastic domain, Hutchinson showed that :<math> J_{\Gamma_2} = -\alpha\,K^{n+1}\,r^{(n+1)(s-2)+1}\,I </math> where ''K'' is a stress amplitude, (''r'',''θ'') is a [[polar coordinate system]] with origin at the crack tip, ''s'' is a constant determined from an asymptotic expansion of the stress field around the crack, and ''I'' is a dimensionless integral. The relation between the J-integrals around Γ<sub>1</sub> and Γ<sub>2</sub> leads to the constraint :<math> s = \frac{2n+1}{n+1} </math> and an expression for ''K'' in terms of the far-field stress :<math> K = \left(\frac{\beta\,\pi}{\alpha\,I}\right)^{\frac{1}{n+1}}\,(\sigma_{\text{far}})^{\frac{2}{n+1}} </math> where ''β'' = 1 for [[plane stress]] and ''β'' = 1 − ''ν''<sup>2</sup> for [[plane strain]] (''ν'' is the [[Poisson's ratio]]).
The asymptotic expansion of the stress field and the above ideas can be used to determine the stress and strain fields in terms of the J-integral: :<math>\sigma_{ij}= \sigma_y \left (\frac{EJ}{r\,\alpha \sigma_y^2 I} \right )^{{1}\over{n+1}}\tilde{\sigma}_{ij}(n,\theta)</math> :<math>\varepsilon_{ij}=\frac{\alpha \varepsilon_y}{E} \left (\frac{EJ}{r\,\alpha \sigma_y^2 I} \right )^{{n}\over{n+1}}\tilde{\varepsilon}_{ij}(n,\theta)</math> where <math>\tilde{\sigma}_{ij} </math> and <math> \tilde{\varepsilon}_{ij}</math> are dimensionless functions.
These expressions indicate that ''J'' can be interpreted as a plastic analog to the [[stress intensity factor]] (''K'') that is used in linear elastic fracture mechanics, i.e., we can use a criterion such as ''J'' > ''J''<sub>Ic</sub> as a crack growth criterion.

{{about|the 2014 film|the entertainment franchise|John Wick}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = John Wick | image = John Wick TeaserPoster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Chad Stahelski]]{{Efn|name=fn1|Stahelski co-directed the film with [[David Leitch (director)|David Leitch]], but the [[Directors Guild of America]] awarded sole directorial credit to Stahelski; Leitch is instead listed as a producer.<ref name="filmstage" />}} | producer = {{Plainlist | * [[Basil Iwanyk]] * [[David Leitch (director)|David Leitch]] * [[Eva Longoria]] * Michael Witherill }} | writer = [[Derek Kolstad]] | starring = {{Plainlist | * [[Keanu Reeves]] * [[Michael Nyqvist]] * [[Alfie Allen]] * [[Adrianne Palicki]] * [[Bridget Moynahan]] * [[Dean Winters]] * [[Ian McShane]] * [[John Leguizamo]] * [[Willem Dafoe]] <!--- per billing block ---> }} | cinematography = [[Jonathan Sela]] | music = {{Plainlist | * [[Tyler Bates]] * Joel J. Richard }} <!-- Per movie poster and opening/ending credits in the film, Tixler already mentioned in prose --> | editing = Elísabet Ronalds | production companies = {{Plainlist | * [[Thunder Road Pictures]] * 87Eleven Productions * MJW Films * DefyNite Films }} | distributor = [[Summit Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|2014|9|19|[[Fantastic Fest]]|2014|10|24|United States}} | runtime = 101 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 101:02--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/john-wick-film | title=''JOHN WICK'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 12, 2014 | accessdate=November 12, 2014}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $20 million<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cdn.esd.ny.gov/Reports/2015_2016/Q1_2016_FTC_Report.pdf|title=Film Tax Credit – Quarterly Report|publisher=[[New York State|Empire State Development]]|date=March 31, 2016|accessdate=July 23, 2017}}</ref> | gross = $88.7 million<ref name="BOM">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=johnwick.htm|title=John Wick (2014)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=December 28, 2014}}</ref> }}
'''''John Wick''''' is a 2014 American [[neo-noir]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/john-wick-2-3-director-chad-stahelski-interview-tv-series-superhero-movie-chapter-prequel-a7786406.html|title=John Wick: Chapter 2 interview: Director Chad Stahelski talks TV series, superhero movies, and Chapter 3|last=Shepherd|first=Jack|date=June 12, 2017|work=[[The Independent]]|access-date=June 16, 2018}}</ref> [[action thriller]] film directed by [[Chad Stahelski]] and [[David Leitch (director)|David Leitch]] from a screenplay by [[Derek Kolstad]]. It stars [[Keanu Reeves]], [[Michael Nyqvist]], [[Alfie Allen]], [[Adrianne Palicki]], [[Bridget Moynahan]], [[Dean Winters]], [[Ian McShane]], [[John Leguizamo]] and [[Willem Dafoe]].
The first installment in the [[John Wick|''John Wick'' film series]], the story focuses on John Wick (Reeves), a retired hitman seeking vengeance for the theft of his vintage car and the killing of his puppy, which serves as a memento of his recently deceased wife (Moynahan).<ref name="John Wick Review">{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/john-wick-review/|title=John Wick Review|publisher=Collider|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> Stahelski and Leitch directed the film together, though only Stahelski was credited.<ref name="filmstage">{{cite web|title=John Wick' Filmmakers on How to Direct Action, DGA, Keanu Reeves' Advice, and More|url=http://thefilmstage.com/features/john-wick-filmmakers-on-how-to-direct-action-dga-keanu-reeves-advice-and-more/|publisher=The Film Stage|date=October 21, 2014|accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref>
Kolstad had completed the screenplay in 2012 and further developed it for [[Thunder Road Pictures]].<ref name="Scorn">{{cite web|url=https://specscout.com/homepage.php?mod=screenplay&smod=coverage&cmd=cvgd&sp_id=766|title=Scorn|publisher=Specscout|accessdate=December 3, 2012}}</ref> The film was produced by Basil Iwanyk of Thunder Road Pictures, Leitch, [[Eva Longoria]], and Michael Witherill. It marks Stahelski and Leitch's directorial debut as a team after multiple separate credits as [[second unit director|second-unit directors]] and [[stunt coordinator]]s. They previously worked with Reeves as stunt doubles on [[The Matrix (franchise)|''The Matrix'' trilogy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Keanu Reeves, 'John Wick' Directors on How Their 'Matrix' Past Helped With Assassin Film|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/keanu-reeves-john-wick-directors-743810|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref>
Stahelski and Leitch's approach to action scenes drew upon their admiration for [[anime]]<ref>{{cite news|title='JOHN WICK' SCREENING: How Keanu Reeves Enlisted His 'Matrix' Doubles To Direct|url=http://zen4zoey.blogspot.co.uk/2014/10/john-wick-screening-how-keanu-reeves.html|accessdate=October 30, 2014|newspaper=Zen For Zoey|date=October 30, 2014}}</ref> and [[martial arts films]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stuntman Inc: The One-Stop School for Action-Movie Stars|url=http://www.mensjournal.com/adventure/races-sports/stuntman-inc-the-one-stop-school-for-action-movie-stars-20140825|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=[[Men's Journal]]|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> The film used [[stage combat|fight choreographers]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Exclusive Video Interview With David Leitch And Chad Stahelski On John Wick|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/exclusive-interview-directors-david-leitch-chad-stahelski-john-wick/|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=We Got This Covered|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> and gun fu techniques<ref>{{cite news|title='John Wick': "Gun-fu" is taken to new heights in actioner about retired hitman seeking revenge|url=http://blogs.orlandoweekly.com/the-gist/for-reels/john-wick-gun-fu-taken-new-heights-actioner-retired-hitman-seeking-revenge/|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=[[Orlando Weekly]]|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> from [[Hong Kong action cinema]].<ref>{{cite news|title=John Wick: Cast Interview with Keanu Reeves, Alfie Allen, directors Chad Stahelski and David Leitch|url=http://zedosgang.blogspot.co.uk/2014/10/john-wick-cast-interview-with-keanu.html|accessdate=October 23, 2014|newspaper=Zedos Gang|date=October 23, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150717123123/http://zedosgang.blogspot.co.uk/2014/10/john-wick-cast-interview-with-keanu.html|archivedate=July 17, 2015|df=}}</ref> The film also pays homage to works such as [[John Woo]]'s ''[[The Killer (1989 film)|The Killer]]'', [[Jean-Pierre Melville]]'s ''[[Le Cercle Rouge]]'' and ''[[Le Samouraï]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=How Sad Keanu got his groove back.|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2014/10/keanu_reeves_action_movie_john_wick_reviewed.html|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> [[John Boorman]]'s ''[[Point Blank (1967 film)|Point Blank]]'', and the [[spaghetti western]] films.<ref name="thesource.com">{{cite news|title=Directors David Leitch and Chad Stahelski Talk New Film 'John Wick'|url=http://thesource.com/2014/10/13/directors-david-leitch-and-chad-stahelski-talk-new-film-john-wick/|accessdate=October 13, 2014|newspaper=The Source|date=October 13, 2014}}</ref> The film was met with positive reviews, with critics calling it one of Reeves' best performances and one of the best action films of 2014. It grossed $88 million worldwide against a production budget of $20 million. A sequel, ''[[John Wick: Chapter 2]]'', was released in February 2017, and another sequel ''[[John Wick 3: Parabellum]]'' is currently filming with a targeted release of May 2019.
== Plot == After John Wick loses his wife, Helen, to a terminal illness, he receives a [[beagle]] puppy named Daisy to help him cope with his grief. He connects with the puppy and they spend their day driving around in his vintage 1969 [[Ford Mustang Mach 1]]. At a gas station, he encounters a trio of Russian gangsters whose leader, Iosef Tarasov, insists on buying his car, but John refuses to sell it. The mobsters follow John to his home that night, knock him unconscious, steal his car, and kill Daisy.
Iosef takes the Mustang to a [[chop shop]] run by Aurelio to have the [[Vehicle Identification Number|VIN]] changed. Aurelio recognizes the car and, upon learning that Iosef stole it from John, punches him before throwing him out of his shop. John visits Aurelio, who tells him Iosef is the son of Viggo Tarasov, the head of the [[Russian mafia|Russian crime syndicate]] in [[New York City]]. Viggo, informed by Aurelio of Iosef's actions, beats and berates Iosef, explaining to him that John Wick was his best assassin, nicknamed "[[Baba Yaga]]". When John wanted to retire and marry Helen, Viggo gave him an "impossible task", implied to involve multiple assassinations. John succeeded, and his efforts were key in establishing the Tarasov syndicate.
Viggo tries to talk John out of seeking retribution, but John silently refuses. Viggo then sends a twelve-man hit squad to John's house, but John kills them all and has the bodies professionally removed. An unsurprised Viggo places a $2-million bounty on John's head and personally offers the [[contract killing|contract]] to John's mentor, Marcus. John seeks refuge at the Continental Hotel, which caters exclusively to the criminal underworld and permits no "business" on its premises. Viggo doubles the bounty for those willing to break the rules to kill John at the Continental.
John learns from Winston, the Continental's owner, that Viggo has Iosef protected at his nightclub, the Red Circle. John enters the Red Circle and kills his way to Iosef, but Viggo's henchman Kirill waylays John, allowing Iosef to escape. John retreats to the Continental to patch up his injuries. Ms. Perkins, an assassin and former acquaintance, sneaks into John's room to kill him, but Marcus alerts John, allowing him to subdue Perkins. He forces Perkins to reveal the location of Viggo's [[front organization|front]], knocks her unconscious and leaves her with fellow assassin Harry to await punishment. However, Perkins frees herself and kills Harry.
John travels to the [[Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn|Little Russia]] church which serves as Viggo's front and destroys Viggo's cache of money and [[blackmail]] material. When Viggo and his team arrive, John ambushes them, but he is subdued and captured. Viggo taunts John for thinking he could leave his old life behind. Before John can be killed, Marcus intervenes again, allowing John to free himself, kill Kirill, and accost Viggo, who reveals Iosef's location. John then travels to Iosef's [[safe house]] and kills him.
Perkins learns that John and Marcus have been in contact and tells Viggo, who has Marcus beaten for information before executing him in his home. Viggo calls John to report this, planning to have Perkins ambush him. Perkins, however, is called to a meeting with Winston, who has her executed for breaking the Continental's rules.
Winston calls John to inform him that Viggo is planning to escape by helicopter. John races to the harbor helipad, where he kills Viggo's remaining henchmen before engaging Viggo in a fistfight on the dock. Viggo pulls a knife, but John allows himself to be stabbed, surprising Viggo. John then disarms and fatally wounds Viggo. Wounded himself, John stops at a waterfront animal clinic to treat his wound and takes with him a [[pit bull]] puppy which was scheduled to be [[animal euthanasia|euthanized]]. John and the dog walk home along the boardwalk where he had his last date with Helen.
== Cast == * [[Keanu Reeves]] as Jonathan "John" Wick :A former hitman who returns to the criminal underworld when a Russian gangster steals his car and kills his dog.<ref name="John Wick Review"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.yahoo.com/movies/mess-with-keanus-puppy-at-your-peril-in-blazing-97633834091.html|title=Mess With Keanu Reeves' Puppy At Your Peril In Blazing John Wick Trailer |author=Arnold, Ben |work=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=September 16, 2014}}</ref><ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES">{{cite web|url=http://www.lionsgatepublicity.com/uploads/assets/JOHN%20WICK%20FINAL%20Production%20Notes.pdf|title=John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES|publisher=[[Lionsgate]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Reeves viewed the character as one who tried to change for love but without his wife he became lost, and returned to the world of assassins in an "[[Old Testament]] revenge story" that possesses him.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/385483/cbb/ultimate-killing-machine-john-wick-back-for-vengeance|title=Ultimate killing machine 'John Wick' back for vengeance|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|accessdate=October 28, 2014}}</ref> The character was written with [[Paul Newman]] in mind,<ref name="Flickering Myth">{{cite web|url=http://www.flickeringmyth.com/2014/10/interview-derek-kolstad-screenwriter-john-wick.html|title=An interview with Derek Kolstad, screenwriter of John Wick|publisher=Flickering Myth|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> originally calling for "a man in his mid-sixties" to play the role, given the title character's fabled reputation. However, head of [[Thunder Road Pictures]] Basil Iwanyk decided against casting an older actor, opting to instead use the stature of a seasoned actor to achieve this effect.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://theactionelite.com/2014/10/screenwriter-derek-kolstad-talks-john-wick/|title=John Screenwriter Derek Kolstad talks 'John Wick'|publisher=The Action Elite|accessdate=October 3, 2014}}</ref> Both Stahelski and Leitch were adamant that Reeves would not learn any martial arts which he had learnt before; for the role, Reeves spent four months learning [[judo]], [[jujutsu]], and [[Brazilian jiu-jitsu]] from "some of the toughest guys" Stahelski and Leitch had encountered, which included their "[[Los Angeles|LA]] [[SWAT]] and [[Navy SEAL]] friends".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/john-wick-87eleven/|title=How JOHN WICK and 87Eleven Taught Me to Shoot People in the Face |author=Dickson, Evan |publisher=[[Collider (website)|Collider]]|accessdate=October 9, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/10/21/keanu-reeves-john-wick/17640977/|title=Keanu Reeves seeks a killer return with 'John Wick' |author= Alexander, Bryan |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/daily/screens/2014-10-24/dont-shoot-the-dog/|title=Don't Shoot the Dog |author= Whittaker, Richard |work=[[The Austin Chronicle]] |accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Grantland">{{cite web|url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/excessive-forces-the-mad-genius-stuntmen-behind-keanu-reevess-dead-dog-revenge-thriller-john-wick/|title=Excessive Forces: The Mad Genius Stuntmen Behind Keanu Reeves's Dead-Dog Revenge Thriller 'John Wick' |author= Patches, Matt |publisher=[[Grantland]]|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> Stahelski spoke of developing a close-quarter combat style that utilised practical grappling forms combined with guns.<ref name="The Credits">{{cite web|url=http://www.thecredits.org/2014/10/stuntmen-turned-directors-light-up-screen-with-john-wick/|title=STUNTMEN TURNED DIRECTORS LIGHT UP SCREEN WITH JOHN WICK|publisher=The Credits|accessdate=October 20, 2014}}</ref> Writer Derek Kolstad chose the character's name to reference his grandfather, the founder of Wick Building Systems. Wick stated, "I was tickled by Derek using my name for a movie, and the hit man character was frosting on the cake." Reeves was paid a reported $1–2 million salary for his role.<ref name="Salaries">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/hollywood-salaries-2016-who-got-933037/item/hollywood-salaries-revealed-who-got-933050|title=Hollywood Salaries 2016: Who Got Raises (and Who Didn't), From Movie Stars to Showrunners|author=THR Staff|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=September 29, 2016|accessdate=October 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://host.madison.com/wsj/news/local/columnists/doug-moe/doug-moe-john-wick-hit-man/article_f9b87a65-abeb-5baa-b5cd-2812c794d854.html |title= Doug Moe: John Wick, hit man |author= Doug Moe, ''Wisconsin State Journal'' |publisher=}}</ref> * [[Michael Nyqvist]] as Viggo Tarasov :The head of the Tarasov crime family and an enterprising businessman with questionable roots.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hamptonroads.com/2014/10/john-wick-%E2%80%94-legendary-hitman-takes-revenge-russian-mob|title=John Wick – Legendary Hit-Man Takes Revenge On The Russian Mob|publisher=[[Hampton Roads]]|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}</ref> Nyqvist was interested in the relationship between characters, Viggo having a father-son respect for John which is ruined by Iosef.<ref name="cinemareview.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemareview.com/production.asp?prodid=18683|title=John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES|publisher=Cinema Review|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Stahelski stated that the role of Viggo had been decided after a great many meetings due to the importance and complexity of the character,<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> noting that Nyqvist's quirkiness contrasted well with Reeves's stoicism. The filmmakers were determined to avoid the stereotypical Russian mobster,<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> with someone who was very charming while a believable bad guy. Iwanyk stated the Nyqvist brought humanity to the character. Nyqvist trained in the Russian [[martial art]] of [[Sambo (martial art)|Sambo]] while also studying his Russian instructors for the role.<ref name="The Credits" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://screenrant.com/john-wick-alfie-allen-michael-nyqvist-interview/|title='John Wick' Video Interview: Alfie Allen & Michael Nyqvist|publisher=ScreenRant|accessdate=October 26, 2014}}</ref> Kolstad said that Viggo had been a street brawler in Kiev who ascended in organized crime and is shifting toward legitimacy.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> [[David Leitch (filmmaker)|David Leitch]] stated that, with input from Nyqvist, they found humorous moments in the script which were carefully paced with the action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joblo.com/movie-news/joblo-gets-into-the-action-at-87eleven-action-design-for-john-wick-278|title=JoBlo.com gets into the action at 87eleven Action Design for John Wick!|publisher=Joblo|accessdate=October 9, 2014}}</ref> * [[Alfie Allen]] as Iosef Tarasov :The arrogant, self-entitled and foolish son of Viggo.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lafm.com/3909-2/|title=Thrilling Revenge Theme Well-Executed in "John Wick"|publisher=LAFM Magazine|last=Riley|first=Tim|accessdate=October 23, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218191301/http://www.lafm.com/3909-2/|archivedate=December 18, 2014|df=}}</ref> Allen found it "invigorating" to play a Russian villain and shoot outside of ''[[Game of Thrones]]''{{'}}s [[Belfast]] set.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-wick-keanu-reeves-willem-740614|title='John Wick': Keanu Reeves, Willem Dafoe Talk "Fantasy" Drifting and Gun Fu Stunts|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=October 14, 2014}}</ref> He was attracted to the role for the [[New York City English|New York accent]] and to work with Stahelski and Leitch.<ref name="The Source">{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2014/10/22/actor-alfie-allen-talks-latest-film-john-wick/|title=Actor Alfie Allen Talks Latest Film 'John Wick'|publisher=The Source|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> While in [[New York City]], Allen visited Russian [[Public bathing|public baths]] to develop and hone the [[Russian phonology|Russian accent]] which he developed for the film<ref name="The Source" /> and faced challenges with the Russian dialog.<ref name="The Source" /> Kolstad described Iosef as a pale imitation of his father, a wealthy heir who believes he is battle-hardened but is just a spoiled punk.<ref name="EmanuelLevy">{{cite web|url=http://emanuellevy.com/review/featured-review/john-wick-keanu-reeves-in-top-form-as-iconic-action-star/ |author=Levy, Emanuel |title=John Wick: Keanu Reeves in Top Form as Iconic Action Star|publisher=[[Emanuel Levy|EmanuelLevy.com]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Allen praised Reeves, who helped him relax on set when nervous.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/john-wick-cast-crew-praise-generous-lead-keanu-reeeves/ |title="John Wick" cast, crew applaud "generous" lead Keanu Reeeves |publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Allen said the film's theme was "all men can change."<ref name="The Source" /> * [[Adrianne Palicki]] as Ms. Perkins :A distinguished female contract killer and a former acquaintance of John.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alisonwillmore/7-things-we-learned-about-the-crazy-assassin-economy-in-john|title=7 Things We Learned About The Crazy Assassin Economy In "John Wick"|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> The character was originally envisioned as a man but was changed by Stahelski, Leitch and Iwanyk who offered the role to Palicki.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> Palicki described the character as a "cold, heartless, conniving, badass" who enjoys her work.<ref name="CraveOnline">{{cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.co.uk/film/interviews/763807-fantastic-fest-2014-adrianne-palicki-john-wick-agents-of-shield|title=Fantastic Fest 2014: Adrianne Palicki on ‘John Wick’ & ‘Agents of SHIELD’|publisher=[[CraveOnline]]|accessdate=September 22, 2014}}</ref> Palicki spent months training at [[judo]] and [[jujutsu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinapse.co/2014/09/30/interview-keanu-reeves-and-adrianne-palicki-talk-about-the-action-of-john-wick/|title=INTERVIEW: KEANU REEVES AND ADRIANNE PALICKI TALK ABOUT THE ACTION OF JOHN WICK|publisher=[[Cinapse]]|accessdate=September 30, 2014}}</ref> Of the character's backstory, Palicki suggested that Perkins knew Wick before his marriage and had a vendetta or rivalry with him.<ref name="CraveOnline" /> * [[Bridget Moynahan]] as Helen Wick :The beautiful wife of John Wick.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> Leitch stated that Helen was the heart of the movie and needed an actress with Moynahan's talents. Moynahan decided not to read the entire screenplay, believing it would serve her performance to only know the loving side of John.<ref name="cinemareview.com" /><ref name="EmanuelLevy" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.complex.com/pop-culture/2014/10/interview-john-wick-keanu-reeves/page/2|title=Keanu Reeves Came Up With a Badass Hashtag for "John Wick"|publisher=EmanuelLevy|accessdate=October 24, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129090256/http://uk.complex.com/pop-culture/2014/10/interview-john-wick-keanu-reeves/page/2|archivedate=November 29, 2014|df=}}</ref> Iwanyk said that Helen was not concerned with John's past life.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> * [[Dean Winters]] as Avi :Viggo's right hand man who has been his lawyer for many years.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> Stahelski stated that Winters brought humor and tension to the role and that the scenes with Winters and Nyqvist were among his favorites.<ref name="cinemareview.com" /><ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> Winters praised Stahelski and Leitch's usage of practical sets and action sequences which did not rely on green screen and special effects, which was a considerable education for him.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/scene/news/keanu-reeves-john-wick-adrianne-palicki-dogs-and-stunts-1201337425/|title=Keanu Reeves, Adrianne Palicki on 'John Wick,' Dogs and Stunts|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> * [[Ian McShane]] as Winston :The enigmatic owner of The Continental Hotel.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wimz.com/content/john-wick|title=JOHN WICK|publisher=[[WIMZ-FM]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219123109/http://www.wimz.com/content/john-wick|archivedate=February 19, 2015|df=}}</ref> McShane described the character as "mysterious" and was attracted to the project due to his fondness for [[neo-noir|modern noir films]].<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> Kolstad noted that Winston speaks little but "the earth moves" when he makes his voice heard.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> * [[John Leguizamo]] as Aurelio :The proud business owner of Aurelio's Garage, a high-end [[chop shop]].<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref name="John Wick">{{cite web|url=http://www.lionsgate.com/movies/johnwick/|title=John Wick|publisher=[[Lionsgate]]|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Leguizamo stated that Aurelio saw the coming storm when Iosef brought John's car to his shop, that Aurelio was going to offend one or the other and had no winning move.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> Leguizamo believed that the costume design created a big boost and had a great impression on him, helping him get into character.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> * [[Willem Dafoe]] as Marcus :A member of the old guard of assassins who is battle hardened, reliable and amongst the elite.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dcist.com/2014/10/out_of_frame_john_wick.php|title=Out of Frame: John Wick|publisher=DCist|accessdate=October 24, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141025102451/http://dcist.com/2014/10/out_of_frame_john_wick.php|archivedate=October 25, 2014|df=}}</ref> Dafoe said that the character was a mentor to John and that they were rare friends in a world of killers.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> Kolstad stated that Marcus had a paternal role as "king of the pride" who was ruthless in seeing the next generation of predators follow him. Dafoe appreciated the original screenplay, which he felt told the story mainly through action, and praised the filmmakers' enthusiasm.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> He felt the project stood out as unique.<ref name="Reeves impresses colleagues">{{cite news|title=Reeves impresses colleagues|url=http://www.goerie.com/article/20141024/ENTERTAINMENT0702/310249993/Reeves-impresses-colleagues|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=Goerie|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> Dafoe stated that the directors' use of gun fu combat created an interesting mix of action<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com">{{cite news|title='John Wick': Keanu Reeves, Willem Dafoe Talk "Fantasy" Drifting and Gun Fu Stunts|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-wick-keanu-reeves-willem-740614|accessdate=October 14, 2014|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 14, 2014}}</ref> with unique choreography integrated into the story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whoaisnotme.net/articles/2014_1014_joh.htm|title='JOHN WICK': KEANU REEVES, WILLEM DAFOE TALK "FANTASY" DRIFTING AND GUN FU STUNTS|publisher=whoa is (not) me|accessdate=October 14, 2014}}</ref>
The cast also includes: [[David Patrick Kelly]] as a "[[Cleaner (crime)|cleaner]]" named Charlie; [[Randall Duk Kim]] as an underworld doctor; [[Lance Reddick]] as Charon, a talented concierge at The Continental Hotel; Munro M. 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hallels.com/articles/11720/20141030/john-wick-trailer-grosses-film-17-million.htm|title='John Wick' Trailer Grosses The Film With $17 Million|publisher=Hallels|accessdate=October 30, 2014}}</ref>
== Production ==
=== Development === {{quote box | quote = Making a movie is actually fairly easy. Making a good one is much harder. It was a huge learning experience and I'm very proud of it. We stretched our schedule to the absolute limits. We fought for what we believed in, and chose to make a story-driven, character-driven action movie. That's why I chose to do it. This was an opportunity to do something that wasn't just about cars, explosions, fire and fights. Yes, John fights; yes, he shoots guns; and he drives a car very fast, but the focus was always trying to do something cinematically different. |source= — [[Chad Stahelski]], on the experience of directing ''John Wick''<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" />{{relevance inline|date=April 2018|This seems like fluff: what isn't mentioned elsewhere could be said in any movie's promotion.}} | align = right | width = 35% }}
The premise for ''John Wick'' was conceived by screenwriter Derek Kolstad who began work on a [[film treatment|treatment]] about a retired contract killer coming out to seek vengeance, entitled ''Scorn''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Derek Kolstad Interview|url=http://theactionelite.com/2012/07/derek-kolstad-interview/ |accessdate=July 30, 2012|newspaper=The Action Elite|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref> After one month of work, he had completed the first draft of the screenplay, and once he had addressed several issues he pitched the script to various clients, garnering at least three offers.<ref name="JOHN WICK, HIT MAN">{{cite web|url=http://www.whoaisnotme.net/articles/2014_0106_joh.htm|title=JOHN WICK, HIT MAN|publisher=whoa is (not) me|accessdate=January 6, 2013}}</ref> Kolstad was influenced by film-noir classics and the themes of [[revenge]] and the [[antihero]] and what might play out if the most evil man found redemption only to have it taken away.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/news/showbiz/movie-review-reeves-returns-wicked-action-flick|title=Reeves returns in wicked action flick|publisher=AsiaOne Entertainment|accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref> The works of [[Alistair MacLean]] and [[Stephen King]] influenced Kolstad in creating the story in terms of world-building and characterisation, respectively.<ref name="Flickering Myth" />
On December 3, 2012, it was announced that [[Thunder Road Pictures]] had bought the script with [[Discretionary spending|discretionary funds]], with Kolstad agreeing due to plans to make the film straight away.<ref name="Scorn" /><ref name="JOHN WICK, HIT MAN" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tracking-board.com/the-hit-list-2012-full-list/|title=THE HIT LIST 2012 (FULL LIST)|publisher=Tracking Board|accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref> When Basil Iwanyk, head of Thunder Road Pictures, had first read Kolstad's original screenplay, he was immediately drawn to the main character of Wick.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> He also admired the emotional weight and action theme of the piece. After Thunder Road had optioned the script, Kolstad spent additional months refurbishing the script with them. In the original script, the character of John Wick was written with "a man in his mid-sixties" to play the role, given the title character's fabled reputation as a revered and respected assassin.<ref name="EmanuelLevy" /> However, Iwanyk was of the belief that this was irrelevant, and rather than casting an older actor looked for a film veteran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movienews.me/2014/10/keanu-reeves-plays-hitman-in-john-wick.html|title=KEANU REEVES PLAYS HITMAN IN "JOHN WICK" – Surprises with Unexpected Use Of Artillery In Action Scenes|publisher=MovieNews.Me|accessdate=October 22, 2014}}</ref>
On May 7, 2013, it was announced that [[Keanu Reeves]] had begun negotiations in April to star in the piece. He was later confirmed as the film's male lead, after Iwanyk and Peter Lawson of Thunder Road showed him the script,<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> which he thought to be full of potential.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies.inquirer.net/15643/keanu-reeves-plays-hitman-in-john-wick-surprises-with-unexpected-use-of-artillery-in-action-scenes|title=Keanu Reeves plays hitman in 'John Wick' – Surprises with unexpected use of artillery in action scenes|publisher=Inquirer EX Movies|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> Reeves and Kolstad had worked closely together on further developing the screenplay and the story,<ref name="JOHN WICK, HIT MAN" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whoaisnotme.net/dedication.htm|title=on his dedication to his craft|publisher=whoa is (not) me|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref> with the screenwriter stating that Reeves understood how even tiny details affect the story's strength.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/movies/news/2014/10/23/1383520/keanu-reeves-film-john-wick-gets-positive-reviews|title=Keanu Reeves film 'John Wick' gets positive reviews|publisher=PhilSTAR|accessdate=October 23, 2014}}</ref> The title of the film was later changed from ''Scorn'' as, according to Kolstad, "Reeves kept telling everyone that he was making a film called 'John Wick{{' "}}, and the producers agreed, changing the title.<ref name="Edgewood">{{cite web|url=http://www.edgewood.k12.wi.us/media/CrusConn14.pdf|title=Alumni and Friends of Edgewood High School of the Sacred Heart|publisher=Edgewood|accessdate=October 22, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129053259/http://www.edgewood.k12.wi.us/media/CrusConn14.pdf|archivedate=2014-11-29}}</ref>
During story discussions, Reeves contacted [[Chad Stahelski]] and [[David Leitch (director)|David Leitch]], who he originally met on the set of ''[[The Matrix]]'',<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview: Chad Stahelski & David Leitch|url=http://dorkshelf.com/2014/10/24/interview-chad-stahelski-david-leitch/|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=Dorkshelf|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> to see if they were interested in choreographing the action<ref name="thesource.com" /><ref name="news.yahoo.com">{{cite news|title=Veteran stuntmen become directors with 'John Wick'|url=https://news.yahoo.com/veteran-stuntmen-become-directors-john-wick-155217192.html|accessdate=October 17, 2014|newspaper=[[Yahoo]]|date=October 17, 2014}}</ref> though he hoped they would direct.<ref name="news.yahoo.com" /> He thought the project and the worlds it created would appeal to them.<ref name="thesource.com" /><ref name="news.yahoo.com" /> The quality of the script and Reeves' enthusiasm convinced Stahelski and Leitch to direct the film. They later presented a thriller version of the story with Wick as an urban legend.<ref name="John Wick PRODUCTION NOTES" /> With Reeves' support, Stahelski and Leitch pitched the idea to the studio, who hired them to direct, contrary to an initial request of directing the film's second unit.<ref name="thesource.com" /> On May 7, 2013, it was announced that Stahelski and Leitch were to direct the film,<ref>{{cite news|title=Keanu Reeves to star in John Wick|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/distribution/keanu-reeves-to-star-in-john-wick/5054693.article|accessdate=May 7, 2013|newspaper=[[Screen International]]|date=May 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Keanu Reeves To Play "John Wick"|url=http://www.darkhorizons.com/news/27028/keanu-reeves-to-play-john-wick|accessdate=May 7, 2013|newspaper=[[Dark Horizons]]|date=May 7, 2013}}</ref> though it was later ruled by the [[Directors Guild of America]] that only Stahelski would be given the director credit.<ref name="filmstage" /> Leitch was credited as a producer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://outtakesatl.com/2014/10/24/john-wick/|title='JOHN WICK'|publisher=Outtakes Atlanta|accessdate=October 24, 2014}}</ref>
Stahelski acknowledged the challenges in balancing the action with the pace and tone,<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com" /> having done this for individual scenes but never before for a whole movie. He acknowledged that action itself should be a collaborative entity with the story, as opposed to being a separate element.<ref name="womanusa.net">{{cite news|title='John Wick': Keanu Reeves, Willem Dafoe Talk "Fantasy" Drifting and Gun Fu Stunts|url=http://womanusa.net/entertainment/movies/john-wick-keanu-reeves-willem-dafoe-talk-fantasy-drifting-and-gun-fu-stunts/|accessdate=October 14, 2014|newspaper=Woman USA|date=October 14, 2014}}</ref> He said they didn't stop the story for an action sequence, but integrated it to provide a deeper feeling of the characters.<ref name="Reeves impresses colleagues" /><ref name="womanusa.net" />
It was remarked by Kolstad, once Reeves, Stahelski and Leitch were officially on board, that from January to September 2013,<ref name="theactionelite.com">{{cite news|title=Screenwriter Derek Kolstad Talks 'John Wick'|url=http://theactionelite.com/2014/10/screenwriter-derek-kolstad-talks-john-wick/|accessdate=October 3, 2014|newspaper=The Action Elite|date=October 3, 2014}}</ref> he was still working on the final drafts of the screenplay, which he described as a "relentless process ... in order to get everyone's vision in check."<ref name="theactionelite.com" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Derek Kolstad Interview|url=http://theactionelite.com/2012/07/derek-kolstad-interview/|accessdate=July 30, 2012|newspaper=The Action Elite|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref>
On September 12, 2013, Willem Dafoe was confirmed to have been cast in the role of Marcus.<ref>{{cite news|title=Willem Dafoe joins Keanu Reeves thriller 'John Wick' |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a515004/willem-dafoe-joins-keanu-reeves-thriller-john-wick.html#~oTGSv9D7Hjmwbg|accessdate=September 12, 2013|newspaper=[[Digital Spy]]|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Willem Dafoe Joins Keanu Reeves in JOHN WICK; Amber Heard Takes to LONDON FIELDS; Jeremy Garelick's THE WEDDING RINGER Adds to Cast|url=http://collider.com/willem-dafoe-john-wick/ |accessdate=September 12, 2013|newspaper=Collider|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> On September 19, 2013, Michael Nyqvist, Alfie Allen, Adrianne Palicki and Dean Winters were confirmed to be a part of the film's supporting cast.<ref>{{cite news|title='Alfie Allen, Michael Nyqvist join Keanu Reeves film 'John Wick'|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a517033/alfie-allen-michael-nyqvist-join-keanu-reeves-film-john-wick.html#~oTGTT5pclx4QYI|accessdate=September 19, 2013|newspaper=[[Digital news|title=John Wick|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/john-wick-2014|accessdate=October 24, 2014|newspaper=[[Roger Ebert]]|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> On October 15, 2013, Jason Isaacs had
